She adds, “At the Amenity Foundation, we are committed to and we encourage this type of crucial educational support for nurses, administrators, and physicians in eastern Iowa.”

“This scholarship is a wonderful example of how an enlightened health care provider can support the community it serves,” says Rita Frantz, the Kelting Dean and professor of nursing. “Wendy and John Boardman’s commitment to preparing nurses for this important work is typical of their thoughtful approach to the health and welfare of Iowa citizens.”

item.title: Morris Bernstein
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: “I immediately considered how I could direct the funding to do the most good.” - Deborah Dawson
item.content:encoded:
Sioux City, Iowa

In 1999, a Santa Monica Mirror columnist made special mention of Morris Bernstein, a 1939 University of Iowa graduate: “Morris Bernstein, my dentist, who recently retired, had a Westside practice for decades. I mention him because a) he was a pillar of the Santa Monica community, b) he had insanely loyal patients, a c) he is a terrific guy.”

Although Bernstein loved serving patients in his adopted home of California, the Sioux City native always considered himself an Iowan first, and he never let go of his Midwestern roots. He visited campus often and maintained close ties with the UI College of Dentistry—and before he died in 2005, he made sure to plant one final seed here: he created the Morris Bernstein Professorship in Dentistry by establishing an endowed fund through the UI Foundation.

Seventy years since Bernstein’s graduation, that seed is taking root. This year, Deborah Dawson, professor and director of biostatistics in the college, became the first recipient of the Bernstein Professorship.

“This is just an incredible honor,” Dawson says. “I immediately considered how I could direct the funding to do the most good. I knew I wanted to support my colleagues’ work as well as my own, and advance important initiatives that will have a positive impact in the community.”

Dawson is using the funds to enhance several of the studies in which she is involved. One project that is being carried out in locations around Iowa focuses on the impact of teaching mothers good oral health practices for their children. Another study in Muscatine is looking at the genetic causes of childhood cavities, and a third is directed toward preventing cavities in Native American children, and exploring community interventions that can reduce disparities in health care for disadvantaged communities.

“These are all public health issues that affect children and families everywhere,” says Dawson. “The outcomes could have a huge impact not only here in Iowa, but around the country and the world.”

David Johnsen, D. D. S., dean of the UI College of Dentistry, says, “Deborah was an easy choice for this honor—she is an outstanding researcher, teacher, and collaborator. If you wanted to exemplify how a professorship should be used, this is the model.”

Endowed faculty support is valuable because it helps the University attract and retain top teachers and researchers and enables them to do their best work. Most important, it ensures that UI students receive the best possible education.

Johnsen notes, “Morris always said he wanted to give back to the college because he felt that he learned more than just professional skills here—he acquired the personal values that guided his life. He wanted to ensure that this well-rounded, quality education continues here for others.”

Says Dawson, “People who make a contribution like this are creating the opportunity to get an idea off the ground, or to accelerate an existing project and attract even more funding. It buys us time to focus on work that can have a significant impact in improving people’s lives.”

Morris Bernstein: a pillar of the UI Dentistry community, intensely loyal to Iowa and the University, and yes, a terrific guy.

item.title: David and Sheila Bennett
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "It's only fitting we give back to the university for making our success possible."
item.content:encoded:
Mahtomedi, Minnesota

With decades of experience in education between them, David (1967 B.A., 1968 M.A., 1971 Ph.D.) and Sheila (1967 B.A., 1969 M.A.) Bennett understand the importance of helping the teachers of tomorrow in whatever way they can.

“Dave and I share a lifelong commitment to enhancing the quality of public education,” says Sheila Bennett. “We believe the foundation for that is the quality of education programs at the university level.”

The Bennetts credit the teachers they encountered while students at the University of Iowa for starting them on their paths to success in education. David and Sheila each received a bachelor’s degree in English and a certification in secondary education from the UI, and both went on to teach at the high school level while pursuing graduate studies. David Bennett eventually earned a doctoral degree in educational administration, while Sheila earned her master’s degree in English education.

After years of work in teaching and administrative roles, the Bennetts look back fondly at the training they received in the University of Iowa College of Education. “In my career as an English teacher and a literacy specialist, I benefited greatly from the excellent preparation I received at Iowa,” says Sheila Bennett. “My gratitude for that runs deep.” Giving back to the UI gives them an opportunity to express that gratitude and lead by example in supporting their alma mater. “Philanthropy is one of the ways we can convey our values,” says David Bennett.

Those values have been clearly expressed through the couple’s bequest to establish the David and Sheila Bennett Fund for Educational Administration, and the David and Sheila Bennett Fund for English Education. The endowed funds will pave the way for promising young educators.

“It’s only fitting we give back to the university for making our success possible,” says David Bennett. “Being able to do so at this stage of our lives is very satisfying, and we believe the UI College of Education is a worthy recipient of our gift.”

The UI College of Education is thankful for generous alumni like the Bennetts, whose contributions help students start, and continue, along their paths to success in education.

item.title: Don and Judy Beisner
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "We challenge today's students, when they're able, to in turn help future students receive an education."
item.content:encoded:
Springfield, Missouri

"Our nation’s most important infrastructure isn’t made up of roads and sewers and bridges," said Donald Beisner (1964 M.D., 1970 R.). "It’s our educational system, from our elementary schools through our universities."

Beisner, an ophthalmologist who died in 2010, and his wife, Judith (1961 B.A.), have helped bolster that educational infrastructure by giving to the University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine (CCOM).

The Beisners, of Springfield, Missouri, worked with the UI Foundation to establish the Judith (Gardner) and Donald H. Beisner, M.D. Professorship for Vitreoretinal Diseases and Surgery.

The Beisners funded their professorship through both outright gifts while Don was living and a bequest. The outright gifts allowed the college to immediately put the professorship into effect, with the bequest—which came to the UI Foundation after Don’s death—completing the endowment of the position.

The bequest, made with a portion of the Beisners’ retirement assets, was part of the couple’s overall estate planning. The deferred commitment enabled the Beisners to have a major impact on the UI Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences—which Don credited with giving him the education he needed to launch his successful career—while helping the UI reach its $1 billion goal in the Good. Better. Best. Iowa comprehensive campaign, which ended in 2005.

"I got a terrific education at a great price," said Don, a native of Cedar Falls, Iowa. "Ophthalmology at Iowa has always been strong and the retina service, led by Dr. Robert Watzke when I was a resident, was especially strong. It’s time to give back."

The Beisners’ support for the UI Carver College of Medicine extends beyond their professorship. Since 1999, the Beisner Scholar Awards have been helping CCOM students with the ever-increasing financial burdens of medical school.

"Excellence breeds excellence, and mediocrity breeds mediocrity," Don pointed out. "Judy and I hope our scholarships can attract very well-qualified students to Iowa. And we challenge today’s students, when they’re able, to in turn help future students receive an education."

In addition, the Beisner Lecture Halls in the Bowen Science Building offer students and faculty an exceptional educational environment. There are three Beisner halls, one named in memory of the Beisners’ daughter, Sarah, who died in 1989; another in honor of Dr. Watzke; and a third in honor of Bruce Spivey (1959 M.D., 1964 M.S.), another former UI teacher and mentor for Dr. Beisner.

"The lecture halls when I was a student were a shame, like giant pits," Don remembered, explaining his motivation for funding the Beisner Lecture Halls. "These new spaces have Internet access and more. What great places in which to teach and learn."

The Beisners have witnessed the effects that a stellar education can have on individuals and on their ability to be of service to their professions and communities.

By giving to the UI and CCOM—in addition to gifts to Iowa State University, the public schools in Cedar Falls, and other educational initiatives at all levels—they’ve done what they can to keep that educational foundation secure and strong.

As Donald Beisner pointed out, that’s the kind of bridge—leading to the betterment of future generations—that is the true backbone of society.

item.title: P. Sue Beckwith, M.D.
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "It's a big project. We're going to need a lot of help and a lot people on board contributing their efforts."
item.content:encoded:
Des Moines, Iowa

As a former University of Iowa Hawkeye women’s basketball letterwinner, Sue Beckwith knows something about being part of a disciplined squad focused on a common goal. But when she started rowing recreationally years later, she really came to understand teamwork.

“Rowing is a wonderful, difficult sport, the ultimate team sport,” Beckwith, a Des Moines surgeon, says. “In basketball, you can take over and take the ball and do something. With rowing, you have to mirror everybody else and do the exact same thing that everybody else does. It’s just a tremendous sport.”

That appreciation for rowing led her to a Hawkeye rowing practice early one morning. The strength and determination of the student-athletes she saw that day—and the conditions in which they worked so hard to represent their University—left a powerful impression on her.

Now, Beckwith has forever altered the future of UI athletics and generations of student-athletes. With the help of her extremely generous leadership gift to The University of Iowa Foundation, the UI has begun work on the P. Sue Beckwith, M.D., Boathouse.

Beckwith, who earned two degrees from the UI (1980 B.A., 1984 M.D.), was motivated to make her gift by her loyalty for her alma mater, her respect for the rowers and their coaches, and—most of all—by the dire need for the rowing team to have a permanent home.

“The team has been housed in the Iowa Advanced Technology Laboratories. When I visited their practice, the rowers had thrown tarps and pads on the floor in between the boats to do their warm-ups,” Beckwith recalls. “There were no restroom facilities, no locker room facilities. We’re not talking about the kids not having some oak-paneled lounge with big-screen TV’s. They have nothing.” 

Thanks to leadership from Beckwith—who has also endowed athletic scholarships for Hawkeye rowers and women’s basketball players—that’s going to change with the construction of the P. Sue Beckwith, M.D. Boathouse.

Fundraising on the project is ongoing. As with the sport Beckwith has come to love, everyone will have to pull together to meet the goals necessary to build a facility which will advance the UI rowing team’s competitiveness in the Big Ten and nationally.

 ”It’s a big project,” Beckwith says. “We’re going to need a lot of help and a lot people on board contributing their efforts.”

item.title: Ida Cordelia Beam
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Because of Ida Cordelia Beam's keen appreciation for education, she had the foresight to include a charitable bequest in her will."
item.content:encoded:
Vinton, Iowa

Ida Cordelia Beam never attended The University of Iowa. She never taught or worked at the UI. And she passed away in 1976. Yet year in and year out, she plays a key role in stimulating the intellectual vitality and vigor of our University.

You might recognize Ida Beam’s name from an ongoing series of campus readings, lectures, and discussions offered by the UI each year. These Ida Beam presentations are given by participants in the Ida Cordelia Beam Distinguished Visiting Professorships Program—some of the best minds in their respective disciplines who come from other world-class institutions to share, and add to, their expertise and insights.

The program has existed since 1978, and the 2010-2011 slate of Ida Beam visiting professors gives a sense of the breadth of its offerings: 11 visiting professors, sponsored by more than 30 UI programs and departments ranging from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop to the College of Law to the Museum of Art to  the Communication Studies Department in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.

Who was Ida Cordelia Beam and how did she come to have such a profound impact on the UI? She was a school teacher who grew up in and around Vinton, Iowa, before living most of her adult life in Oregon until her death at age 96. Because of her keen appreciation for education, she had the foresight to include a charitable bequest in her will, leaving her family’s farm in Benton County, Iowa, to The University of Iowa Foundation. The farm was sold, according to her wishes, and the proceeds were used to establish the program in her name.

You, too, can have a lasting influence on the life of the UI. If you include a charitable bequest—of real estate, cash, life insurance benefits, or other assets—in your estate plans to support any area of the University, you can be assured of leaving an Iowa legacy while retaining the right to modify the bequest as your and your family’s needs evolve. Be sure to tell us about your bequest—confidentially and at no obligation to you—so we can ensure that it’s used to carry out your philanthropic goals.

item.title: Janice Baumback
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "My family owes the UI a whole lot. More than we can ever pay back."
item.content:encoded:
Iowa City, Iowa

Janice Baumback (1971 M.S.W.) is a woman who makes choices with care.

“My family owes the UI a whole lot. More than we can ever pay back,” said Baumback, who was married for nearly 50 years to the late Clifford Baumback (1953 Ph.D.), a professor in what is now the UI Henry B. Tippie College of Business.

That’s why she chose to create the Clifford M. Baumback Entrepreneurial Studies Award in the Tippie College of Business, and the Janice S. Baumback Graduate Student Award in the School of Social Work, which is part of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.

Born in Shanghai, China, Janice Baumback came a long way to become so committed an Iowa fan. Her father was a professor at Jiao Tong University until she was five, when the family relocated to Seattle during China’s bloody civil war.

She received a B.A. degree in sociology from the University of Washington in 1944 and had nearly completed work on an M.B.A. degree at Northwestern University when she met and married Clifford. The two moved to Oklahoma when he was offered an academic position, then to Iowa City, where he completed a Ph.D. degree in industrial management.

Clifford overcame a decade of serious health problems and began teaching in the UI business school in 1962. When he retired in 1980, he was a nationally renowned expert in the field of small business. He died in 1995.

In 1968, Janice made a key decision in her life, returning to school for an M.S.W. degree—attending the UI along with two of her three grown children. She enjoyed a 14-year career as a social worker in the UI Department of Child Psychiatry—and stays in touch with some of the families she served.

Service remains central to Baumback’s life—her commitments reveal thoughtful choices about giving back to the community. The scholarships she created will benefit many generations of UI students, and she volunteers many hours to help local human services organizations.

She also made gifts in the form of a charitable gift annuity (CGA) to the UI Museum of Natural History and Hancher Auditorium.

“I’m altruistic, but I’m also a pragmatist,” she said. “With a CGA, one can invest in programs that one believes in—especially programs like these that so enrich our lives—and also receive a guaranteed income at an attractive rate of return.

“We’re all given three things in different proportions: time, talent, and treasures, and we must choose what to do with them,” said Baumback. “I believe it’s our responsibility to use these gifts to help the community.”

Some decisions come easy—and The University of Iowa is grateful for the choices Baumback has made.

item.title: Dale E. and Linda R. Baker
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "When I returned from my own experience in Romania, I thought it would be great to be able to send students on the trip as well."
item.content:encoded:
Iowa City, Iowa

For Dale and Linda Baker, the seeds of philanthropy were sown long ago.

“My dad always said he never wanted to be the richest guy in the cemetery,” says Linda Baker. “I guess that has always stuck with me.”

Linda Baker’s father was a successful certified public accountant in Evanston, Illinois. He took classes over the years at Northwestern University, though rules requiring on-campus residency at the time prevented him from receiving a degree. He still believed strongly in the value of higher education, and even helped fund the college education of one of Linda’s friends in need.

“When you’re able, help out other students,” Linda Baker recalls her father saying. And the Bakers did just that, helping a friend of their son’s with college costs years later.

Dale and Linda Baker met as freshmen on the UI campus, sharing their first date at a Hawkeye men’s basketball game at the old Field House on a blustery winter night. They both graduated from the UI in 1968—Dale with a B.B.A. degree in business administration and accounting, and Linda with a B.A. degree in English and a secondary education certification—and were married in July of that year.

The Bakers’ belief in giving back has touched countless students and faculty at their alma mater over the years. They have long been generous supporters of various UI programs and initiatives, and are platinum members of the University of Iowa Presidents Club. Most recently, they made a gift of more than $1 million to the UI through the University of Iowa Foundation—support that will benefit people throughout campus and well beyond.

A $250,000 portion of the gift was made to endow the Dr. Ken Magid Child Advocacy Service Scholarship fund. The scholarship, administered by the University of Iowa Alumni Association, was established in 2005 by Linda Baker to honor her mentor, Dr. Kenneth Magid, whose wide-ranging career had a tremendous influence on her own career and service efforts. The fund helps UI students cover expenses related to volunteer service-learning opportunities in orphanages in Romania. Linda Baker traveled to Romania with the UI Alumni Association’s Iowa Voyagers program in the spring of 2005 to work for three weeks in an orphanage and was so moved by the experience that she established the scholarship.

“When I returned from my own experience, I thought it would be great to be able to send students on the trip as well,” says Linda Baker. When she shared that thought with Diane Baker, who is not related to Dale and Linda Baker, in the UI Alumni Association, the idea to fund the scholarship was born. “It was a true case of two heads being better than one,” says Linda Baker.

In addition to the scholarship gift, the Bakers made a gift of $1 million to the UI Alumni Association Vision Endowment Fund. The Vision Endowment Fund helps provide stable, long-term financial support to enhance connections between Iowa alumni, friends, and the UI.

“Creating secure sources of funding is important as it helps satisfy the ongoing need to reach out to different age groups, and the need to experiment with ways to keep different people connected to the UI,” says Dale Baker.

Despite the decades that have passed since graduation, the Bakers maintain their connection to the UI campus through their philanthropy. They also remain connected to the many friends they met during their time as students, as well as new UI friends they’ve made since—thanks in part to events facilitated by the UI Alumni Association.

“One of the many things the UI Alumni Association has to offer is also a lot of fun,” says Dale Baker. “We’ve met some fantastic people over the years through events they’ve coordinated.”

item.title: Robert J. “Bob” Assink
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: “I just really needed to support this. It is critical to support researchers with good ideas who need funding to develop their work.”
item.content:encoded:
Cedar Rapids, Iowa

When faced with the prospect of losing his vision and the ability to enjoy the theatre, Robert J. “Bob” Assink took action. It was a sobering and frightening possibility for someone with a longtime appreciation for the theatre arts—a very visual experience—in both his professional and personal life.

Bob, who lives in Cedar Rapids, made a sizable bequest to The University of Iowa Foundation to create the Robert J. Assink Glaucoma Fund, which will support research for prevention and treatment of the disease within the Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences in the UI academic medical center. He established the fund to assist Young Kwon, M.D., Ph.D., with his clinical care, teaching, and research—and more broadly, to support the department’s mission of excellence.

When Bob, who received a B.A. degree in speech and theatre from the University of Northern Iowa in 1962, visited his local ophthalmologist, David Puk, for a routine eye exam, Puk saw a problem in his patient’s eyes that needed to be dealt with. As a UI alumnus, Puk immediately referred Bob to Kwon, one of Puk’s former teachers, at UI Hospitals and Clinics. Bob was impressed with the connection that remains between Puk and Kwon, as well as the level of service and expertise he received at the UI. Because of Kwon’s professional, patient, and personal manner, Bob knew he was in good hands at the UI.

To help maintain the quality of care in the department of ophthalmology, as well as increase and improve the treatments for glaucoma, he has participated in several research studies. Now, through the fund he has established, Bob will be able to help even more with the fight against glaucoma.

Bob, who retired in 2002, spent his life teaching high school speech, theatre, and other language arts, and he is highly committed to supporting education at all levels. Through the treatment he has received as a glaucoma patient at the UI, he has seen how research and education go hand in hand in an academic medical center like Iowa’s.

“Without the work of the department and my highly skilled doctors, I might be blind right now,” said the Cedar Falls, Iowa, native. “I just really needed to support this. It is critical to support researchers with good ideas who need funding to develop their work.”

Bob is grateful that the several surgeries he has had have prevented him from experiencing vision loss. And he is proud that, through making decisions now about how he’d like his estate assets used later, he can play a role in sustaining the unification of education, research, and clinical care in the work of doctors like Kwon at The University of Iowa.

item.title: Rose Garfinkle
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "The cancer center was a protective, caring environment. I felt comfortable and safe there."
item.content:encoded:
Birthdays mean a lot more to Rose Garfinkle these days. “Every year, I’m just thankful to be alive,” she says. “It’s like icing on the cake.”

In 1994, when Rose was 38, a physician at the UI’s Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center (HCCC) confirmed her worst fears: The breast cancer she thought she’d beaten—with a mastectomy two years earlier at HCCC—had returned.

With a three-year-old daughter and a husband at home, and a demanding career as a graphic designer and manager, Rose was catapulted into a world of uncertainty and turmoil. Fortunately, though, she was under the care of the expert staff at HCCC, one of America’s premier cancer centers. And from the oncologists to the receptionists, they set to work caring for Rose—not just physically, but emotionally as well.

Supported by generous contributions large and small, the center is truly a comprehensive one, providing compassionate care for patients like Rose and advanced research so fewer cancer patients will need that care in the future.

HCCC arrranged for Rose to speak with other women who’d been through the same ordeal, women who became Rose’s good friends. The center was responsive to her questions and needs. Her husband, Barry Markovsky, was welcomed into the process; when Rose stayed in the hospital for a month following an autologous bone-marrow transplant, Barry spent much of that time by her side writing the Rose Report, a newsletter about her progress that he sent to friends and family. One nurse was assigned to Rose throughout her time at the center, assuring continuity and familiarity. Rose had ready access to the hospital’s library.

Rose sums up the experience this way: “The cancer center was a protective, caring environment. I felt comfortable and safe there.”

All the while, Rose was undergoing advanced, aggressive treatment featuring bone-marrow transplant techniques that had been developed partly by UI researchers. That extensive treatment saved her life. No longer a cancer patient, Rose has become a cancer survivor, thanks to HCCC.

“I’m incredibly proud to be part of the survivor community,” she says.

Now Rose, who has since moved from Iowa City to Columbia, South Carolina, gives back to HCCC and fellow survivors. She serves on the center’s Advocacy Board. She offers support to other women, just as patients before her did for her. And most of all, she’s a believer in the power of advanced medicine joined with compassionate, patient-centered care—the specialty of the Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center.

item.title: Dr. Mark E. Wilkinson
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "We couldn't be more grateful for the generosity of those who help us in our mission."
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Mark E. Wilkinson, the director of the Low Vision Rehabilitation Service, a program of the Center for Macular Degeneration in UI Hospitals and Clinics, sees the impact of private support daily. And because of that support, the individuals who benefit from the program’s services can see everything more clearly.

“Our program provides a full continuum of services—medical, physical, psychological, and social—to help individuals with impaired visual functioning lead more productive, satisfying lives,” Dr. Wilkinson says.

“The range of devices we offer runs the gamut, too,” he says, “from special reading glasses to magnifiers and telescopes to video magnification devices.”

Of course, such devices can be expensive to acquire, and health insurance generally does not provide coverage for them. Fortunately,
private gifts help bridge the gap, allowing this innovative program of UI Hospitals and Clinics to better serve the residents of Iowa and the region.

“We couldn’t be more grateful for the generosity of those who help us in our mission,” Dr. Wilkinson says. “
Because of them, we are able to empower people to live life to the fullest.“

item.title: Jack Lynch
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "When an opportunity came, I wasn't denied the chance to seize upon it just because I didn't have the financial ability to go."
item.content:encoded:
As a 34-year-old single parent, Jack Lynch decided to give his dreams a shot. The Iowa City native had been working at UI Hospitals and Clinics, but his true love was the theatre. So he went back to school to nurture his talent.

After doing some undergraduate work at the UI, Jack received his degree at another university. But when it came time for graduate school, the UI offered him an opportunity to create a self-styled M.F.A. program in theatre, which included dance. He thrived—and with a special boost given to him by contributors to the Iowa Impact Fund, he has gone on to establish a successful and fulfilling career in theatre.

While in the graduate program, Jack received an opportunity to travel to New York City to perform an original piece at the prestigious and influential La Mama Experimental Theatre. It was an opportunity he couldn’t pass up, but he couldn’t afford the trip. He tried to get help from various University sources—but the specific designations for those funds didn’t match his need.

Performing in New York, however, would clearly be an important step for this talented artist’s career, so the director of his M.F.A. program requested funding from the unrestricted Iowa Impact Fund (which was then known as the Iowa Opportunity Fund).

With these unrestricted resources, the UI was able to step in quickly and help cover costs for the trip—and because of thoughtful contributors, Jack’s life was forever changed for the better.

Jack says, “Because of the Iowa Impact Fund, when an opportunity came, I wasn’t denied the chance to seize upon it just because I didn’t have the financial ability to go. I will always be grateful for that.“

Now Jack, who received his M.F.A. in theatre arts in 1996, lives in London, directing and nurturing his passion for teaching at the esteemed Guildford School of Acting. In 1999 he and his wife, actor and UI graduate Edie Campbell (she earned her M.A. degree in English in 1993) formed their own theatre company, LynchPin Productions.

Recently Jack returned home in an exciting fashion—in March 2002, he and Edie came to Iowa City to produce their one-woman play, Emily Dickinson and I, which has received critical acclaim in London and at the Edinburgh Festival, at Iowa City’s Riverside Theatre.

All Jack needed was a chance. Thanks to the Iowa Impact Fund, he got that chance and is still making the most of it.

item.title: Heidi Bernau Wagler
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "The physicians and staff got to know my mother so well; they really care personally about every patient."
item.content:encoded:
An important part of Kay Bernau’s legacy is easing the suffering of other women as they fight breast cancer.

Kay felt so strongly about the positive treatment she received at the Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center (HCCC) that after she died of the disease in 2003, her family decided to use the memorial gifts to establish a special patient-care fund.

Today, the Kay Bernau Fund for Breast Cancer Compassionate Patient Care is helping patients get through treatment that can be both physically and emotionally challenging.

Kay’s daughter, Heidi Bernau Wagler, joined the HCCC’s advocacy board after her mother’s death, assisting the volunteer group in focusing on advocacy, fund raising, and public relations for the center.

“The Holden Center really goes above and beyond in the way they treat people,” says Heidi. “The physicians and staff got to know my mother so well—they really care personally about every patient.”

The center’s extraordinary treatment came even closer to home for Heidi when she herself developed breast cancer in 2005 and was successfully treated at the Holden Center. “When I found the lump, I went straight to my mother’s doctor. He took so much time with me, I felt as though he would have been willing to answer my questions all afternoon.”

Within a week, Heidi had a diagnosis and started treatment. Thankfully, the disease was discovered early, and her prognosis is excellent—good news for her husband and three children.

The experience made the Bernau family feel even more strongly that creating a fund at the center—giving back in gratitude for their exceptional experience at the HCCC—was the right thing to do.

“The staff members were so sensitive to my mother’s and my needs. They’d often give us little gifts or show personal gestures of kindness,” she says.

“The fund we created provides special care for women who might not be able to afford ‘extras’—for example, women in chemotherapy often find that their fingers get numb. The fund might pay for a manicure or pedicure—or in some way provide assistance and comfort.”

Supported by generous contributions large and small, the Holden Center is one of only 39 “National Cancer Institute Comprehensive Cancer Centers” nationwide, a title that recognizes a comprehensive approach encompassing the areas of cancer care, research, and education.

“Because I serve on the HCCC advocacy board, I know how crucial private support is to the center,” says Heidi. “Whether a gift is supporting the little things that help a patient feel better, or research that may one day lead to a cure for breast cancer, every gift makes an important difference.”

She adds, “It means a lot that we could honor my mother’s memory—and her caring nature—in this way.”

item.title: David Gompper
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I’m so blessed to be at Iowa."
item.content:encoded:
Last May, when University of Iowa faculty member David Gompper accepted a prestigious Academy Award in Music from the American Academy of Arts and Letters in New York City, the honor was a milestone in Gompper’s ongoing career as a composer, performer, conductor, and teacher—and a testament to the UI’s longstanding reputation as a pioneer in the arts.

The occasion was also a demonstration of the enduring power of philanthropy in advancing the arts and an institution like the UI. Gompper is the director of the Center for New Music (CNM)—a performance organization devoted to the late 20th- and early 21st-century repertoire—in the School of Music, which is part of the UI College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. The CNM was initially established by a pair of matching grants from The Rockefeller Foundation in the 1960s, and has been Gompper’s creative home since 1991. As the trailblazing accomplishments of Gompper and the CNM continually prove, those far-sighted gifts have been paying dividends to the University, and to music, for more than four decades.

Here’s how The Rockefeller Foundation explained its motivation for supporting music at the UI in its 1965 annual report: “Of special interest to The Rockefeller Foundation are the possibilities inherent in working with colleges and universities which are genuinely hospitable to the arts of the present, especially those institutions which are willing to innovate on their own campuses . . . There is today a growing sense of awareness in many of our universities that the creative arts should be included in the regular academic curriculum on the same footing as the recognized disciplines of knowledge.” Because the UI was the world’s first university to accept creative work in music, theatre, writing, and art on an equal basis with academic research—as far back as the 1920s—Iowa was a natural fit for The Rockefeller Foundation’s support. The report continued, “Several universities—notably Buffalo, Chicago, Rutgers, and Iowa—have, with the help of The Rockefeller Foundation, established creative centers in music, bringing together composers and performers to vitalize the musical life of the university campus, but even more to stimulate the musical thinking of the entire region.”

The CNM has lived up to the potential that the foundation saw for musical stimulation, thanks in large part to Gompper’s impassioned dedication to the CNM’s mission.

As UI President Sally Mason says, “The School of Music has a legacy of innovation, and the Center for New Music has played a critical role in that tradition for over 40 years.” College of Liberal Arts and Sciences Dean Linda Maxson agrees, saying, “The Center for New Music plays a vital role in our college’s longstanding commitment to fostering creative work, and David—both as a composer and a colleague—exemplifies the best of the best in our School of Music.”

Gompper, building upon the work of the CNM’s founders, Richard Hervig and William Hibbard, and the subsequent leadership of D. Martin Jenni, sustains a fertile creative environment at the CNM. Through the center, graduate composition students, working with musicians from throughout the School of Music, develop their talent and present their work locally, nationally, and internationally. Students have accompanied Gompper—who taught at the Moscow Conservatory as a Fulbright Scholar in 2002 and 2003—on performance tours around the U.S. and in Europe.

The CNM also provides a venue for music students to gain firsthand exposure to contemporary music, an element often lacking in the training of classical musicians. “Our students are really great musicians,” Gompper says, “but outside of the center, there are few opportunities for them to play recent and challenging contemporary music. So the center is a magnet for these students who need to have these kinds of experiences and show aptitude for this kind of work.”

Composers from around the world have brought their work to the CNM to have it performed as well. A short list of visiting composers of note—some of whom have premiered works at the UI—includes George Crumb, Charles Wuorinen, Morton Feldman, Gunther Schuller, Lukas Foss, and Libby Larson.

The CNM under Gompper’s direction has organized important festivals and programs that have captured the music world’s attention, such as the Russian Contemporary Music Festival in 2000 that was reviewed on the front arts page of The New York Times.

And on top of all those CNM activities, Gompper is an extraordinary performing pianist, regularly playing around the world, from communities in Iowa and the Midwest to Vienna, Moscow, Prague, and Ecuador.

It all adds up to a recognition throughout the contemporary music world that the UI is among the leaders of 21st-century innovation in new-music education and creation. Essentially, The Rockefeller Foundation’s gifts long ago created the conditions where a renowned artist such as Gompper—and the students he teaches—can find a creative home and advance Iowa’s reputation in valuable ways, and Gompper is thankful for the opportunity that the CNM has given him. “I’m so blessed to be at Iowa. I’m a very fortunate person,” says Gompper, whom the UI recently awarded a major Arts and Humanities Initiative grant, which he will use to have four of his works recorded by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London.

Now, as the UI works to overcome the effects of the 2008 flood that destroyed much of the arts campus—including the Voxman Music Building, which housed the School of Music—more such visionary philanthropic support will be crucial to ensure that the UI’s flagship arts programs can continue to excel. “As we rebuild our arts campus for the 21st century, we are dedicated to infusing our plans with the spirit of originality and vision that has long characterized the Center for New Music, the School of Music, and all of our fine-arts programs,” says President Mason.

It will be up to all of us to pull together for the future of the arts at Iowa, through support for new facilities and the faculty and students who will work there. And—as with the gift that created the UI’s Center for New Music—today’s investments will resonate in future decades throughout the University and the global arts community.

The Center for New Music and its director, David Gompper, have released a steady stream of recordings and regularly perform concerts at the UI, across the U.S., and around the world. For concert schedules, discographies, biographies, reviews, and other information, visit these websites: http://www.uiowa.edu/~cnm/ and http://www.davidgompper.com/.

item.title: Brandon Cochran
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I never would have had these opportunities without contributors' generous investments in the Pentacrest Museums."
item.content:encoded:
Brandon Cochran knows much more about ground sloths and Iowa’s first legislators than the average person. That’s because the University of Iowa graduate gained an in-depth understanding of both these topics while majoring in anthropology and working as a student intern—and then an employee—at the UI Museum of Natural History and Old Capitol Museum.

After graduating from Iowa in 2006 with a bachelor’s degree and a certificate in museum studies, Brandon accepted a position in museum operations at the Johnson County Historical Society Museum.

He is passionate about the role of museums in both campus and community life. “The Pentacrest Museums are just incredible cultural, ecological, and historical resources. They’re such a valuable part of our Iowa identity, and they’re here for everyone—from students and schoolchildren to teachers and parents,” says the St. Marys, Iowa, native.

“These Museums offer a catch-all for people; they can come to one destination—the UI campus—and experience the best of Iowa history and culture. When people give to the Museums, they help keep that experience alive and growing.”

During his work with the Pentacrest Museums, Brandon helped the Museum of Natural History name its new Biosphere Discovery Hub and assisted in preparing Old Capitol Museum for its grand reopening in May 2006, after a November 2001 fire and subsequent renovation.

“I did everything from writing text labels for exhibits and surveying museum users to serving as a docent and adjusting Old Capitol’s historic bell,” Brandon says. “I never would have had these incredible opportunities without contributors’ generous investments in the Pentacrest Museums.”

Such generosity is what made it possible for Brandon to gain the skills he needed to find work in his field after graduation. And though he’s no longer working for the Pentacrest Museums, he continues to bring Iowa history and culture to life every day.

item.title: Sharon Lee Smith
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I wish I could personally thank all supporters of the Graduate College's fellowship programs."
item.content:encoded:
“I was heavily recruited by a number of other universities, but the UI just felt more like home,” says graduate student Sharon Lee Smith. “When I was an undergraduate, I participated in the Graduate College’s Summer Research Opportunity Program. This program helped me to both mature as a student and to determine that environmental engineering was my path.”

Several excellent graduate engineering programs recruited Sharon, and some offered financial packages beyond what the UI had been able to offer. Then the UI Graduate College stepped in, offering Sharon a prestigious Graduate Merit Fellowship.

“I cannot say enough about how much the Graduate College has offered me as a student and person,” says Sharon. “I hope one day to become a college professor and to use my Iowa graduate degree to help developing countries maintain a clean water supply.”

Sharon’s story is more than one of individual triumph: She began working toward her Ph.D. degree with two young sons—Jaylen, 5, and Marquis, 6—in tow. The Graduate College offered her additional funding to help her move from Louisiana and resettle her family in Iowa City.

“To be successful you have to be happy,” Sharon points out. “The Graduate College’s financial support and the warm, friendly environment the Graduate College promotes have been key to my success as an engineering student. I wish I could personally thank all supporters of the Graduate College’s fellowship programs.”

item.title: Sukriti Nayar
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Gifts show commitment to excellence in education, and they give people an opportunity to pursue that excellence."
item.content:encoded:
Sukriti Nayar was looking for “a reputable experience in a reputable institution” when she began considering colleges. That’s why she chose the University of Iowa.

The double major in accounting and finance has seen enough of the world to know a good experience in a good place when she finds one. She was born in India and then lived for a time in South Africa before moving to Iowa to become a student in the Henry B. Tippie College of Business.

This global background helped prepare Sukriti for the world of opportunities that she and her classmates have found at Iowa. Unsure of what she wanted to pursue after high school, she counts the breadth and depth of choices at the UI among the reasons she chose to attend. “Iowa had such a large variety of paths for me,” Sukriti says. “I’m absolutely happy with my choice.”

Sukriti’s academic experience has not been confined within the walls of the Pappajohn Business Building on campus. In addition to her business degrees, she also is on track to receive a minor in English. This helps her work as a writing tutor, a role for which she receives scholarship support.

In addition to the compensation she receives for tutoring, Sukriti has benefited from other forms of private support as well. She is the recipient of an Old Gold Tuition Scholarship and the Marion A. Youngers Accounting Ethics Scholarship, and she also has received awards from the Rhodes Dunlap Endowed Hours Fund, the Tippie College of Business Scholarship for Women Fund, and the Dore Business Communications Center/Writing Assistants Fund.

Sukriti regularly expresses her gratitude, with letters of thanks, to those who have made gifts. She also has a message for anyone who is thinking about making a gift, of any amount: “Sometimes gifts aren’t as visible, the donations not as flashy. But they all add up,” she says. “Gifts show commitment to excellence in education, and they give people an opportunity to pursue that excellence. People who give are creating a whole fleet of young professionals.”

Thanks to the support she’s received and the academic achievement she’s enjoyed, Sukriti can soon count herself among those young professionals. With graduation on the horizon in May 2012, Sukriti already has secured a job in Chicago, working with a transaction service advisory where she’ll use her accounting skills to advise on mergers and acquisitions.

Sukriti believes that she and her classmates have been successful at Iowa because of what she calls its “human capital”—the connections with peers and mentors, the wisdom and advice from various faculty members, and the opportunities for global experience.

“We succeed with a sense of community,” she says.

item.title: Sarah Langlas
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Every little bit of support can create something new."
item.content:encoded:
To pursue her interest in business, Sarah Langlas considered schools all over the country. But she was raised a Hawkeye fan by her father and other relatives who attended The University of Iowa, and Sarah wanted to be part of the tradition.

From the moment she stepped onto campus, the University of Iowa Henry B. Tippie College of Business student from Wheaton, Illinois, has benefited from private support in ways she hadn’t anticipated. Sarah has built a network of peers and business professionals through the Tippie Scholar program and presentations coordinated by the Young Alumni Board. She has received writing and resume assistance through the Judith R. Frank Business Communications Center and guidance from a program checklist plan that helps students in different majors get on the right track early.

These resources help Sarah, who is on the UI varsity soccer team, efficiently manage her time and prepare for the business world she’ll enter after graduation.

Sarah is grateful to the generous alumni and friends who enable her to take advantage of so many diverse resources. “The more program variety the Tippie College of Business can offer, the more students will get involved and contribute,” says Sarah, a recipient of the Old Gold and Heritage Scholarships, who wants to attend graduate school after working for several years. “Every little bit of support can create something new.”

item.title: Ryan Bentzinger
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Having scholarship money meant I didn't need as rigorous a work schedule outside of school."
item.content:encoded:
Ryan Bentzinger (2011 B.A.)—like many before him—was initially drawn to the University of Iowa by the richness of its writing tradition. While the Pella, Iowa native did not end up pursuing writing academically, he noticed instantly the larger arts tradition present at the UI, and knew he wanted to be a part of it.

“Iowa City is so open-minded and supportive of the arts,” says Ryan. “The relationship between the city and the university is so important.”

Ryan graduated in May of 2011 with a bachelor’s degree in studio arts from the University of Iowa College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, and a K-12 teaching certification from the University of Iowa College of Education. Getting to that point was not always easy, Ryan says, and he credits the teachers at the UI—from teaching assistants to professors—for creating the opportunities he seized upon in pursuit of his degree.

“The teachers all care so much about what they’re doing,” he says. “Students can get as much out of the experience as they want.”

Ryan’s own experiences were facilitated in part by the financial assistance he received—as the Belin-Blank Honors Award recipient, and as the recipient of a UI tuition scholarship for his senior year.

“Having scholarship money meant I didn’t need as rigorous a work schedule outside of school,” he says. “I had time to produce artwork in my free time instead of having to work a nightshift for extra money.”

Financial support also freed Ryan up to be on the giving end of philanthropy, volunteering hundreds of hours to local schools while a UI student. Practicing his craft and giving of himself are, he believes, ways of thanking his supporters.

“The best way to show thanks is through success, to prove my supporters right,” Ryan says. “Financial support opens doors, and doesn’t just get you into the game, but ahead of it.”

item.title: Mark and Mary Jo Abbott
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Contributing to the Parents Fund and taking an active role in the Parents Association seemed like a natural extension..."
item.content:encoded:
For Iowa Hawkeye football fans, Mark Abbott’s voice is a familiar one—he’s the announcer for the games at Kinnick Stadium. But he and his wife, Mary Jo, have another important role as a voice for UI parents and their children.

Mark and Mary Jo, whose daughter, Leslie, is a UI senior majoring in Spanish and elementary and secondary education, are contributors to the Parents Fund for Student Support, which provides resources for vital student-centered projects throughout campus.

They are also members of the Parents Association’s board of directors, helping to guide the group’s work on behalf of other UI parents.

“All UI parents are automatically members of the Parents Association,” Mark points out. “We help the UI provide safe and fun activities and programs that go beyond what the UI itself is able to do, especially in these tight budget times.”

The Parents Fund for Student Support is instrumental in enabling those efforts.

“The board directs Parents Fund resources toward programs that we think will have maximum positive impact on students’ lives,” Mary Jo says. “Often, initiatives need seed money to give them the chance to prove themselves. Other times, programs are well established and we want to see them continue.”

Mary Jo, who earned a B.S. degree in pharmacy from the UI in 1971 and works as a pharmacist at UI Hospitals and Clinics, and Mark, a 1973 UI law graduate who works as an assistant to the director of athletics at the UI, like to be involved in the lives of their children and the University.

“We learned a lot from the UI. We believe in being advocates for the University,” Mark says. “And we were always involved in our kids’ activities in high school, so contributing to the Parents Fund and taking an active role in the Parents Association seemed like a natural extension of that.

“It’s an easy and effective way to help students have the best possible UI experience.”

item.title: Rachel Revelez
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Being a donor means so much because the difference you make is tangible."
item.content:encoded:
Growing up in West Liberty, Iowa, Rachel Revelez remembers traveling with her family to Iowa City on most weekends. During each of those trips, Rachel’s parents would point out the University of Iowa campus, telling her she would “go there someday.”

Years later, she did exactly that.

Now a junior majoring in elementary education in the UI College of Education, the pieces of campus that once zipped past the window of her family’s car have become Rachel’s daily surroundings—and she knows she’s in the right place.

“I couldn’t have imagined going anywhere else—it wouldn’t have felt right,” she said.

Rachel is the recipient of the 2012 Edgar M. and Evelyn Benzler Tanruther Scholarship, which was established through the estate of Edgar Tanruther and is awarded to elementary education students. The scholarship will help Rachel offset the costs of pursuing her degree. “I was awarded the scholarship right around the time I was running out of money to pay off my U-Bill,” Rachel said. “It meant a lot to me to get that scholarship at just the right time; it almost felt like someone was looking out for me.”

During her time on campus, Rachel has done plenty of looking out for others as well, practicing the kind of philanthropy she feels fortunate to have received. As a peer leader in Iowa Edge—an early orientation program for minority and first-generation college students—she gives of her time to enhance the college experience of others. Rachel was a mentee in the program when she arrived on campus, and describes the experience as “life-changing.” She credits the program with helping her succeed as a UI student—success she’s thrilled to foster in others.

“Being a peer leader for Iowa Edge has definitely been one of my most shining moments here at the university,” she said.

Rachel also has received an Advantage Iowa Scholarship and a tuition scholarship through the UI Office of Student Financial Aid. She says the various forms of support she has received have helped her succeed, and she hopes future donors will look at stories like hers and realize the impact they can have.

“Being a donor means so much because the difference you make is tangible,” she said. “What can mean more than that?”

item.title: Rachel Crome
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Private support was essential in enabling me to come to the UI, where I’ve had countless leadership roles."
item.content:encoded:
Gifts from generous UI alumni and friends have benefited Rachel Crome personally and, in return, contributed to her ability to help others.

Rachel, a student in the University of Iowa College of Engineering, has served on the fundraising committee for the University of Iowa Society of Women Engineers, participated in Habitat for Humanity, and helped organize a 5K “fun run” to benefit the Johnson County Shelter House. This involvement was possible because she received the Lichtenberg Scholarship, which allowed her to focus on her studies and volunteerism rather than working to make ends meet.

The scholarship was also an essential component in the Stockton, Illinois, native’s decision to attend the UI. The manageable size of the UI campus, combined with the resources and opportunities available at other large institutions, also attracted Rachel.

Some of the resources within the college that have been particularly beneficial, and a direct impact of gift support, are the student group activities work space and a new computer lab in the Seamans Center. The group work space provides a communal location for engineering students to complete team projects and hone their technical skills with new, easy-to-use equipment. And the new computer lab, which Rachel uses three times a week, has eased crowding.

Rachel is thankful for the support that comes from those whom she has never met. “It’s hard to give money to someone whose face you’ve never seen,” says Rachel, who plans to work at an environmentally friendly company after graduation. “I’m in awe of that kind of generosity.”

item.title: Nia Aitaoto
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I could never repay donors for what they've given, but I'll do my best to give to the next generation."
item.content:encoded:
For Ph.D. student Nia Aitaoto, the Aloha spirit of her home state of Hawaii can also be found in Iowa.

“The University of Iowa is special,” says Nia. “People are very humble and nice, and I really appreciate that about Iowa.”

After completing her undergraduate and graduate studies in community health at the University of Hawaii in Manoa, Nia coordinated health programs in Hawaii and the Pacific Islands for nearly a decade before coming to the UI to pursue a Ph.D. in Public Health with a concentration in health communication.

Nia was recently awarded a prestigious R21 grant from the National Institutes of Health to study diabetes prevention in Hawaii and the U.S. Pacific Islands.

“Being here at The University of Iowa enabled me to easily find faculty experts for my research team,” says Nia. “The relationships between the colleges here are so strong that I was able to assemble this great group of people without having to go beyond the University.”

Gifts from alumni and friends are crucial to Nia’s UI student experience not only because they support top-notch faculty. She also received the college’s Dean’s Fellowship.

“I could never repay donors for what they’ve given, but I’ll do my best to give to the next generation,” Nia says. “In my culture, when someone gives you something, it’s a responsibility. Now I’m responsible for that gift.”

item.title: Natalia Lawson
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "It's so meaningful that someone would be willing to help us get this experience and this education. I'm amazed that people are willing to do that."
item.content:encoded:
The reputation of the University of Iowa Physical Therapy and Rehabilitation Science program first piqued Cedar Rapids, Iowa, native Natalia Lawson’s interest in it. She had heard about the quality of the program, and about how well prepared its graduates were for work in their field upon graduation. And while that has proven true for her in her time in the program, she found something else she loved when she arrived on campus, something harder to measure but every bit as important.

“There was a great community atmosphere here,” said Natalia.

That sense of community—on campus and off—has helped Natalia and her classmates take their learning beyond the classroom, a must in a field like physical therapy. Natalia works in a hospital, in addition to her studies, and also volunteers her time through local Elder Services, Incorporated, as an in-home visitor to elderly clients. “It’s all about expanding your horizons,” Natalia said of the UI community. “I’m very happy here.”

Natalia came to the UI after completing undergraduate studies at the University of Northern Iowa. Originally a special-education major, Natalia’s eyes were opened to the possibilities of physical therapy while she was an undergraduate. Now in her second year at the UI, Natalia isn’t sure what her focus will be within the field of physical therapy, but she is sure that the experiences she’ll have within the program will help her sort that out.

As the recipient of scholarships from the School of Physical Therapy and the Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine, Natalia is thankful for the private support she has received.

“There’s not enough I can say in the way of thanks,” said Natalia. “It’s so meaningful that someone would be willing to help us get this experience and this education. I’m amazed that people are willing to do that.”

item.title: Morgan Siegrist
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I'm amazed at the quality and range of education and research opportunities that it offers."
item.content:encoded:
“Just a decade ago, the UI College of Public Health didn’t even exist. Today, I’m amazed at the quality and range of education and research opportunities that it offers. Private contributions are important to this growth.”

As a student pursuing a Master of Public Health for Practicing Veterinarians degree—a collaborative program between the UI and Iowa State University—Morgan Siegrist looks forward to combining her passion for animals with an interest in public health and safety.

Private gifts help make this innovative program possible by providing faculty support to attract and retain a broad range of public health experts, and program support to provide the technology enabling students like Morgan to take some of her UI classes online. Thanks to alumni and friends of the College of Public Health, today’s public health students will become the professionals who ensure our safety tomorrow.

item.title: Morgan Fulmer
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Your gift makes a strong statement about the importance of mentoring and empowering the next generation."
item.content:encoded:
Kansas native Morgan Fulmer grew up with a passion for science. After completing her undergraduate studies at the University of Kansas, that interest put the University of Iowa on her radar. Now in her second year in the University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine Physician Assistant Program, Morgan couldn’t be happier with her choice.

“The strength of the program drew me here,” said Morgan. “But when I first toured, it was the students that really sold it for me. I’m incredibly happy with my choice.”

In addition to loving science, Morgan also loves working with people. She has found plenty of opportunities to connect with people while participating in the McCowen Learning Community—where she is the Donations Committee sub-chair on the Philanthropy Committee—and serving on the Student Leadership Committee within her college. This past fall, she journeyed to India to work in various clinics with underserved populations.

While others are already benefiting from her own philanthropic work, Morgan has found herself on the receiving end of philanthropy as well. The recipient of the Physician Assistant Departmental Grant, a University of Iowa Foundation Departmental Grant, and the Rex Montgomery Biochemistry Award, Morgan says private financial support was part of what sealed her decision to attend the UI.

“The University of Iowa was my first choice anyway,” Morgan said. “But the financial support was really crucial in allowing me to come here. I would not have had the means to do so otherwise.”

Due to graduate in May 2012, Morgan isn’t sure what her focus will be for her career search. She is interested in neurology, oncology, and internal medicine, but she is keeping an open mind. Armed with the experiences she’s had at Iowa—and that same passion for science that first drew her to the UI campus—a bright future awaits Morgan and her patients.

item.title: Megan Danforth
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "We realize that sometimes alumni and friends aren't here to see the fruits of their giving, but I hope they know that it relieves a lot of the stress!"
item.content:encoded:
Growing up in Shenandoah, Iowa, Megan Danforth (2007 B.S.) always knew she wanted a career in the health-care field. A mentor and family friend helped her decide dentistry was the right field for her. And Megan, who also did her undergraduate studies in Biology at Iowa, said the decision to continue her studies at Iowa was an easy decision to make.

“Iowa’s dental college is one of the top in the nation,” says Megan. “The reputation of the program, combined with in-state tuition—in my mind there was no better choice!”

Megan is reassured every day that she’s on the right career path. And she’s grateful for the private donations that support facilities like the college’s simulation clinic.

“Right away we learn by doing,” says Megan of the simulation clinic. “It’s one of the best qualities of Iowa’s program—you get tools in your hands right away to develop those important hand skills.”

After graduation, Megan plans to settle in small-town Iowa to practice dentistry. And the financial support she’s received while in school will allow her to do that.

“We realize that sometimes alumni and friends aren’t here to see the fruits of their giving, but I hope they know that it relieves a lot of the stress of our day-to-day work. So thank you!”

item.title: Maribel Treto
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I wanted to come to Iowa because when I came to visit, I felt really welcome. But if I didn't have these scholarships, I would've had to stay in Illinois for school."
item.content:encoded:
In high school, Maribel Treto realized she had special skills in the areas of science and math, and decided to study engineering at The University of Iowa after an exciting college visit day.

“I came on the day of an Iowa vs. Iowa State football game,” says Maribel. “Students were decked out in black and gold, and everyone was very welcoming and full of school spirit.”

The senior chemical engineering major, who hails from Melrose Park, Illinois, is happy with her decision to come to The University of Iowa.

“The College of Engineering is small, it’s personal,” says Maribel. “I really know my professors, and they know me by name.”

This is especially important to the first-generation college student.

“I definitely have the support of my family; they know college is important,” says Maribel. “But when it comes to academic requirements or what to expect during my college career, I’ve had to rely on my professors and advisor for that information. And they’ve been really helpful.”

Private support has been crucial to Maribel’s college experience. She received an Advantage Iowa scholarship, a merit-based award given to students who will contribute to a diverse learning environment, and an Alcoa Scholarship for Diverse Engineering Students.

“I wanted to come to Iowa because when I came to visit, I felt really welcome,” says Maribel. “But if I didn’t have these scholarships, I would’ve had to stay in Illinois for school,” she notes, adding that out-of-state tuition would have been a financial burden for her family.

Gifts from UI alumni and friends enabled her to focus on academics and gain practical experience doing internships, including one with Schlumberger, an oilfield services provider in Alaska.

Maribel looks forward to working in her chosen career after graduating in May 2011. She also hopes to be able to give back to the UI. “I want to share with others and help them grow.”

item.title: Kelsey Cermak
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: “I’m thankful every day. I’ll look back on it as a great experience for the rest of my life.”
item.content:encoded:
Kelsey Cermak, an Iowa Hawkeye forward from Norwalk, Iowa, was recruited by several colleges, including the University of Northern Iowa and the University of Nebraska. But none of them had a chance. “I grew up a Hawkeye fan,” Kelsey says. “It wasn’t a hard choice. Being a Hawkeye was always my ultimate goal.”

Being offered a scholarship clinched the deal. “It means a lot,” she says. “Coach Bluder gave me a chance. I’m thankful every day. I’ll look back on it as a great experience for the rest of my life.”

The Hawkeyes are just as thankful to have Kelsey, a communications major who was an academic all-Big Ten honoree in her sophomore and junior years, wearing the black and gold. She has been a solid contributor to her team both on the court and off. Her selection as the recipient of the team’s Dr. Christine Grant Leadership Award and the Kris Rogers Memorial Scholarship speaks volumes about the respect she’s earned among her fellow student-athletes and her coaches.

Kelsey’s scholarship support during her four years at Iowa has also included the Bill and Kay Pitlik Women’s Basketball Scholarship and support from the Colloton Fund for Women’s Athletics. During the summer of 2010, Kelsey traveled to I-Club golf outings and lunches as an intern at The University of Iowa Foundation, so she knows well the importance of scholarship support from Hawkeye fans. “We wouldn’t be here without them,” she points out.

She also is grateful for the support that UI alumni and friends have shown for the Carver-Hawkeye Arena renovation project. Though she won’t see the results as a player, she knows just how crucial it will be to the success of those who follow in her footsteps.

“They’ll be able to go in whenever they want to practice,” she says. “They won’t have to schedule around other teams. The weight room and locker rooms will be up to date. It will be a huge help with recruiting, and will really help the coaches.”

Kelsey sums up her gratitude for Iowa Athletics supporters succinctly: “Being a Hawkeye has been the best experience I’ve ever had—and you’re part of the reason why.”

item.title: Kelly Nagle
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I’m glad for the opportunity to be in a great program like REACH."
item.content:encoded:
When Kelly Nagle first arrived on the University of Iowa campus, her dream was to someday be an actress or a singer. After one year of classes, her plans have changed dramatically.

“I realize now that I want to have a more realistic goal,” says Kelly, who hails from Overland Park, Kansas. “I want to work with people and help them.”

Kelly, who has Down syndrome, is enrolled in the UI College of Education’s Realizing Educational and Career Hopes (REACH) program, a two-year certificate track for young adults with multiple intellectual, cognitive, and learning disabilities. Much of the REACH curriculum is focused on career preparedness, and during the second year, students participate in an internship with a local business.

Through courses centered on career exploration, Kelly has discovered that she enjoys helping people and would like to prepare for a career in elder services. With additional instruction in personal finances, technology, and health and life skills, Kelly is quickly gaining the confidence and problem-solving skills that she hopes will lead to more independence upon graduating from REACH.

“I’ve learned so much about personal responsibility,” says Kelly, “but with tons of support.”

And though Kelly says it was hard to leave her family, her transition to college went smoothly. She enjoys her classes and fills her weekends with a variety of on- and off-campus activities.

“I like living in the residence halls,” says Kelly. “And it’s fun meeting new people.”

Kelly’s advisor, Janis Mendenhall, has enjoyed watching Kelly adjust to campus life.

“Kelly has done really well with meeting new people, and quickly made friends with students in and out of the REACH program,” says Janis. “She’s doing well here.”

Kelly’s mother, Mimi, agrees.

“I thought Kelly was pretty independent and mature when she went to school,” says Mimi. “But when she came home for Christmas break she had such confidence, and her problem-solving skills had really improved. She really works at things on her own now before coming to us for help.”

Mimi is thrilled for Kelly to have this opportunity and is grateful for gifts to the REACH Fund.

“When we started this process, I was surprised at the lack of federal assistance for students with intellectual disabilities,” says Mimi. “So private support has been extremely helpful.”

Kelly is looking forward to her internship and plans to find a job in Iowa City after graduation.

“It’s wonderful here,” says Kelly. “This has been an opportunity of a lifetime. I’m glad for the opportunity to be in a great program like REACH.”

item.title: Kayla Pollock
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Your assistance and devotion to the University of Iowa has been felt on a personal level."
item.content:encoded:
From a town of not quite 700 to a campus of more than 30,000, Kayla Pollock (B.A. 2010) expected many things to change when she chose to leave home and attend the University of Iowa.

“Coming from a very small town, I was used to having a tight-knit community of support around me at all times,” says Kayla. But thanks to the support she has received at the UI, that small-town feeling hasn’t been as elusive on campus as she had expected.

The philanthropy of donors—people who, in Kayla’s case, she has never met—plays a large role in that community feel. “Receiving financial support from people I’d never even met reminded me a lot of the camaraderie of my small town,” says Kayla.

If the small-town camaraderie of campus surprised Kayla, the quality of UI academics did not. Two older siblings preceded her to campus, and their experiences—coupled with the UI’s “esteemed liberal arts background”—were enough to pique her interest when she began considering colleges. Iowa City’s designation as an international “City of Literature” by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) during Kayla’s time on campus has only bolstered the value of her UI education, she says.

Kayla graduated from the UI in 2010 with a bachelor’s degree in English. She married shortly after graduation and chose to remain in the area—an “easy decision,” she says, for her and her husband—to pursue a master’s degree in Library and Information Science and a K-12 Iowa teaching certification at the UI. Her decision was further validated when she was awarded the Gladys and Margaret Harvey Education Scholarship by the University of Iowa College of Education in 2012.

The scholarship was established by Margaret Harvey in memory of her sister, Gladys Harvey, and is awarded to undergraduate or graduate students in the College of Education. Receiving the scholarship reduced Kayla’s financial stress, allowing her to concentrate more fully on student teaching in the fall of 2012. Although she did not get the chance to meet her benefactor, Kayla knows what she would say to her if she could.

“Donations are so much more than simple transactions,” she says. “Your assistance and devotion to the University of Iowa has been felt on a personal level, which is something that is not always easy in an institution of this size.”

item.title: Kapri Saunders
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "There are so many people who have given and have helped me succeed. The best I can do is say 'thank you,' and then go do good in the world."
item.content:encoded:
When Kapri Saunders started looking at law schools, she took out a map of the United States, and crossed out all the states she would never live in.

“Iowa was one of them,” Kapri laughs.

But then she met someone who had attended the College of Law at The University of Iowa, and he raved about the program and Iowa City. After researching the program, she included UI in her application process and eventually chose Iowa. She made the move from Tempe, Arizona, and hasn’t looked back. “I can’t imagine having gone to law school anywhere else,” she says.

Kapri, who completed her undergraduate studies at Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff, has settled in well in Iowa City. She’s currently editor-in-chief of the Journal of Gender, Race and Justice, which is a donor-supported publication now in its 15th year. And Kapri has been thrilled with the opportunities private support to the law school has afforded her, including work in the college’s Clinical Law Programs where she’s able to work on real family law and immigration cases under the supervision of law faculty.

After graduating in May, Kapri will move to Cleveland, where she will clerk for a federal district court judge in the Northern District of Ohio.

“There are so many people who have given and have helped me succeed,” says Kapri. “The best I can do is say ‘thank you,’ and then go do good in the world.”

item.title: Kaitlyn Kemna
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Donors start a chain reaction by supporting graduate students who as teaching assistant support me and help me discover my passions. "
item.content:encoded:
Kaitlyn Kemna was very nervous when she arrived at The University of Iowa for the start of classes, but special interactions with teachers assured her that she had chosen an extraordinary university.

Kaitlyn graduated from a high school class of just 57 in Mason City, Iowa. She initially wanted to go to a small university, but family members who had attended the UI encouraged Kaitlyn to challenge herself.

Early in Kaitlyn’s sophomore year, her sister was diagnosed with kidney disease, and it was determined that Kaitlyn would be the donor. It was remarkable, Kaitlyn said, how understanding and accommodating her teachers were during that period, before they even knew her. “It sounds cheesy,” says Kaitlyn, “but I’m really not a number here.”

In addition to giving each student a personalized experience, the UI recognizes that students need flexibility in determining their areas of study. A teaching assistant helped Kaitlyn, who began as a biology major, realize she enjoyed history much more. “I’m appreciative that I was able to actively explore different areas of interest,” says Kaitlyn.

The key role that donors have in supporting teachers, like the ones that had such a positive influence on Kaitlyn, has opened Kaitlyn’s eyes to the importance of giving. She was inspired to become involved with the Student Philanthropy Group, an organization on campus that informs students about the importance of philanthropy and the ways donors’ gifts of all sizes touch so many aspects of the university experience.

Because of her experiences and involvement with the philanthropy group, Kaitlyn firmly decided to become a donor herself one day. She looks forward to being a part of making students’ time at Iowa well-rounded and exceptional. “I don’t know many people who wouldn’t want to be part of that,” says Kaitlyn.

item.title: Julie Qidwai
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I barely have to leave my desk, which allows me to spend more time analyzing than searching. Thanks!"
item.content:encoded:
Julie Qidwai knows a good library when she sees one. The Cedar Falls, Iowa, native and graduate student in industrial engineering grew up around libraries. And she couldn’t be happier with the ways the UI Libraries network—with the help of its generous contributors—has enabled her to conduct research through its varied, user-friendly services.
