Julie’s father is the archivist at a university library and her mother, a university instructor, has a degree in library science. Now Julie finds herself immersed in the finer points of a university library.

As a researcher at the UI’s National Advanced Driving Simulator, studying the effects of alcohol and drugs on driving behavior, Julie—who earned a B.S. degree in psychology from the UI in 1999—says, “I use the Libraries’ online services almost every day. I use InfoHawk to find out whether the University possesses publications I need. Being able to access online full-text versions of recent versions of many journals has been a godsend.”

She adds, “If the Libraries don’t have what I need, I can submit a request to Interlibrary Loan, where they do their very best to find my citations, even when the details are lacking. The Libraries’ Government Publications department has also ordered a number of reports from the Department of Transportation for me to use.

“In short,” says Julie, “I barely have to leave my desk, which allows me to spend more time analyzing than searching. Thanks!”

From extensive collections to excellent service, the University Libraries system has it all, thanks in large part to thoughtful and loyal contributors. And as Julie makes clear, the Libraries system helps make the work of UI community members—undergraduate and graduate students as well as faculty and staff—possible.

item.title: Jostten Sackitey
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Those gifts have been so impactful on my education. Higher education opens so many doors, and without private support, those doors would be closed for some."
item.content:encoded:
Jostten Sackitey had only a stretch of interstate between his birth home and the University of Iowa. However, when his family moved from Des Moines to Philadelphia, Pa., after he was born, the miles grew, and the road meandered. He didn’t know then that he would one day return to Iowa to finish out high school—and to attend the University of Iowa.

He has never regretted that move.

“It’s hard to imagine having a better time or getting more out of the experience than I have,” said Jostten.

Jostten’s first love was in the sciences, and his initial exposure to the UI campus was during a glaucoma-research program he participated in during the summer after his senior year in high school. He saw a wealth of opportunity awaiting him during that experience.

“I was attracted to Iowa because it had the broadest, deepest resources and expertise in the areas I was interested in,” he said.

Now a double major in economics and finance in the Henry B. Tippie College of Business, Jostten has discovered that this breadth and depth extends well beyond the sciences. Through his involvement in the Iowa Edge Program—an initiative designed to help underrepresented populations transition to college—as well as several clubs and organizations, Jostten has taken his learning, and his leadership, beyond the classroom. After graduation in May 2012, he will begin work immediately for Google’s treasury department.

The beneficiary of private support—with scholarships from the E. Lester and Frances M. Williams Fund and the Earl A. Wimmer Business Scholarship Fund—Jostten is thankful for the opportunities he has received.

“Those gifts have been so impactful on my education,” said Jostten. “Higher education opens so many doors, and without private support, those doors would be closed for some.”

In fact, he plans to help open doors for others someday. “It’s only right that I do someone else the favor,” said Jostten.

item.title: Johnathan Gajdos
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I’m grateful to alumni for continuing the legacy of giving that started when they were in school, and I’m happy to carry it on for another generation."
item.content:encoded:
There is something special, says Johnathan Gajdos, about the University of Iowa Graduate College in that it is committed to excellence in a wide range of disciplines.

The excellence in the Department of German drew Johnathan to the UI after completing his undergraduate studies at Georgetown University. Upon his first visit, he was impressed with the people he met on campus as well as by the University’s facilities.

That positive impression hasn’t faded six years later thanks to funding from generous alumni and friends that has enhanced Johnathan’s time at the UI. Johnathan was awarded the Presidential Graduate Fellowship, which allowed him to concentrate on research and his dissertation without needing to make ends meet by teaching undergraduates during each year of study. The fellowship included four summers of support in which he studied linguistics at a Linguistic Society of America Institute at Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and learned Swedish in Sweden.

Private support also funds the annual James F. Jakobsen Graduate Conference, which provides an opportunity for graduate students like Johnathan to present their research and work, and be recognized for their efforts, right on campus.

Johnathan, who grew up outside of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is grateful to those who make these experiences available. He is so confident in the Graduate College’s use of funds that he has already begun his own legacy of giving at the University.

“I know my small contribution doesn’t make a huge difference, but I want to start somewhere,” says Johnathan. “It’s a symbol of my support and trust in the Graduate College’s awareness of students’ needs and wants.”

item.title: Jessica Orseno
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Private gifts allow students to advance beyond what the classroom can offer."
item.content:encoded:
In the midst of her major Midwest college tour, Jessica Orseno came across an interview with an alumna of The University of Iowa in her local newspaper. In response to being asked what her favorite city was, the interviewee said, “Iowa City. Hands down.”

This sparked an interest in Jessica. When she subsequently visited Iowa City, Jessica felt comfortable immediately. The compactness of such a large university, positive interactions with current University of Iowa Henry B. Tippie College of Business students and the opportunity for several scholarships sealed Jessica’s decision to become a Hawkeye.

As an accounting student from Homer Glen, Ill., set to graduate in May 2011, Jessica has had the chance to spend two weeks studying international environmental business in London with fellow Tippie College of Business students and has been involved with Beta Alpha Psi, an honors accounting fraternity that provides professional development for students while emphasizing community service.

In addition to these opportunities, private funding supports and retains exceptional faculty members who have pushed Jessica beyond getting good grades to developing an intuition for accounting concepts and interacting with the management teams of local businesses.

Jessica is grateful for the many teachers at Iowa who have helped her excel, and for the gifts from generous individuals that support them and enhance the university experience. “Private gifts allow students to advance beyond what the classroom can offer, making us more marketable, involved and well-rounded people,” says Jessica.

item.title: Jenna Le Roy
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I want to make proud all the people who have invested in my education."
item.content:encoded:
Private scholarship support gave Jenna LeRoy the freedom to decide her medical specialty based on the most important criteria: how much she enjoys the work. This means a lot to Jenna when she considers the possibility of choosing other specialties with shorter degree-completion periods just so she could quickly pay back her loans.

Jenna came to The University of Iowa from Clinton, Iowa, to take advantage of a first-class, in-state institution. She received a bachelor’s degree from the UI in 2007 before continuing on at the University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine.

The physicians at Iowa are a source of constant inspiration to Jenna, who plans to pursue a pediatric residency after graduation. She has great respect for those who strive to continue learning about the changing field of medicine while maintaining superior patient care. Jenna intends to thank those who contribute to the annual fund each year by dedicating herself to becoming a great physician like those she’s encountered at Iowa.

“My scholarship meant that this school has faith in my abilities,” says Jenna, who received the Medicine General Scholarship, a product of annual giving, in addition to several other scholarships. “Knowing this makes me work harder so that I can honor the UI’s belief in me and the generosity of the people who made such a wonderful gift.”

item.title: James Vandenberg
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "These generous people have given me a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, in both academics and athletics."
item.content:encoded:
Hawkeye starting quarterback James Vandenberg understands and appreciates the power of private scholarship support.

Vandenberg has been a quarterback since the first grade, when he fell in love with the game of football. He has been a Hawkeye fan since he was ten years old, when his parents, Ann and Toby, moved to Keokuk from Washington State.

“Having a scholarship to attend this University is a huge privilege, and something I take very seriously,” said Vandenberg, who is studying integrated physiology at the UI. “It is something I am thankful for every day, because Iowa football and the Falb family (James is the recipient of the Mark Falb Quarterback Scholarship) are giving me a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, in both academics and athletics. I am very grateful to them.”

Vandenberg’s appreciation for private support and the important role it plays for so many student-athletes only deepened when he worked as an intern at the UI Foundation in the summer of 2011.

Vandenberg said, “The internship was an awesome job opportunity, and an eye-opening experience. I couldn’t believe how much donors have given to support student-athletes. Not only has it given me a deeper sense of gratitude for the support I’ve received, it has also made me look forward to being a donor some day – and passing it on.”

Executive Director of Development at the UI Foundation, Matt Henderson, said “We’ve had a long line of impressive student-athletes intern with us, and James was no different. He was wonderful with our donors. He has such a genuine appreciation of people and their passion for the Hawks that he draws people in. He truly feels it is an honor to be a Hawkeye, and shows sincere generosity with his time. He is an ideal representative of our student-athletes and I know that Mark (Falb) is very proud of his association with James.”

item.title: Jacob Shell
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I am grateful for the private support that has helped me make the most of my opportunities at Iowa, and I absolutely plan to pay it forward one day by giving back to others—and to my alma mater"
item.content:encoded:
A high-school job in a drugstore in his hometown of Spirit Lake, Iowa, first sparked Jacob Shell’s interest in becoming a pharmacist. In that job, he saw pharmacists interacting with the public—and building relationships—and he knew he wanted to do the same.

“I saw how those relationships affected the patients’ overall health care,” Jacob said. “I wanted to be that accessible to people.”

Jacob now is a third-year student in the University of Iowa College of Pharmacy, and he was drawn to the school because of its strong national reputation. Since arriving at Iowa, he has seen for himself how the college has earned that reputation, and he has benefited from the plentiful opportunities for students to get involved.

Jacob seized one such opportunity through service in the College of Pharmacy Student Leadership Council, an organization for which he now serves as president. As part of this role, Jacob serves on the Iowa Pharmacy Association Trustees, and he also assists with the college’s various community outreach efforts.

With plans to graduate in May 2013, Jacob isn’t certain where his career path might lead. He likes the idea of working in a small community pharmacy like the one in his hometown, and he thinks he might like to try his hand at management down the road. He’s hoping his last year in the program will help him decide.

“I hope my rotations help shed some light on that for me,” Jacob said in describing the field experiences he’ll have in his final year.

He is grateful for the private support that has helped him make the most of his opportunities at Iowa, and he “absolutely” plans to “pay it forward” one day by giving back to others—and to his alma mater.

item.title: Jacob Kirpes
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I wouldn't be here without donors and the scholarships they provide. Without them, I wouldn't be on this track."
item.content:encoded:
Jacob Kirpes has never regretted his decision to attend the University of Iowa.

“There’s no other place for me to be,” said Jacob. “It’s become a home for me.”

The Des Moines native considered other places to pursue his college goals, but ultimately chose the UI in part because of the private support that awaited him. Jacob is the recipient of the William C. Power, Jr., Scholarship, an R. Milton Pierce Memorial Scholarship, and an award from the James R. Whiteley Grand Challenges Scholar Fund, a three-year program focusing on interdisciplinary studies. In summer 2011, Jacob also received the Ann Morse Study-Abroad Scholarship, an award that facilitated a study-abroad experience in Italy.

“I wouldn’t be here without donors and the scholarships they provide,” Jacob said. “Without them, I wouldn’t be on this track.”

That track includes an ambitious double major: industrial engineering in the College of Engineering and finance in the Henry B. Tippie College of Business. When he graduates in December 2013, he hopes to pursue a career in supply-chain finance.

Jacob credits his academic success to a faculty that fully engages students. He also credits facilities such as the Engineering Building, within which he has had the opportunity to learn and network with peers.

“The building is so well-kept,” Jacob said. “It has great technology, and it’s a great place to study and hang out with friends.”

He hopes future students can benefit from private support the same way he has. And he counts himself and his fellow future graduates among those future contributors, thanks to the success they’ve been able to enjoy at the UI.

“We look forward to giving back,” said Jacob. “That would be rewarding.”

item.title: Gabe Darrow
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Thank you for investing in the Tippie College's amazing people and programs—and for helping to change my life!"
item.content:encoded:
“Private support for the college helped me take advantage of everything from the London study-abroad program to real-world internships. With those experiences on my résumé, I know I’ll be successful after graduation.”

Gabe Darrow knows that amazing teachers really can change lives. Thanks to an influential high-school teacher who encouraged him to apply to the Henry B.Tippie College of Business, Gabe has benefited from life-changing UI experiences that include interning at MidWestOne Bank and working for a hedge-fund placement agent in London. “My classmates and I have had many firsthand experiences like these,” says Gabe. “They’ve taught us that Iowa business students really can compete with the Ivy Leaguers!”

item.title: Farah Towfic
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "My gratitude for donors’ support will be demonstrated in the exceptional care I plan to give patients. "
item.content:encoded:
Farah Towfic has donors to the University of Iowa College of Pharmacy to thank for her recent trip to Las Vegas. But Farah wasn’t in the city to gamble. She attended the American Society of Health-Systems Pharmacists Clinical Meeting in December 2009—an invaluable opportunity to strengthen her knowledge and make personal connections with colleagues in her field of choice.

Opportunities like this one make Farah proud to be part of the UI College of Pharmacy. She chose Iowa because she recognized the value in the close relationship the program has with the UI Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine and the Colleges of Dentistry and Public Health, allowing a collective community outreach effort and an interdisciplinary perspective.

Farah will take advantage of this partnership to learn and develop an understanding that will improve the overall health of her future patients.

As a pharmacy student, Farah has also felt the impact of alumni support in other ways. She has been an intern at a community pharmacy, served as a student trustee on the Iowa Pharmacy Association Board of Trustees and benefited from a tuition scholarship.

The student from Dubuque, Iowa, is grateful for every opportunity she’s had. “In the years ahead I know I’ll be following the example of the current alumni by giving to the UI so that students like me can develop professionally and become future leaders,” says Farah. “My gratitude for donors’ support will be demonstrated in the exceptional care I plan to give patients, and the more students who come through this program, that many more patients will benefit.”

item.title: Erin O’Dell
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Scholarship assistance allows me to focus on my studies without having to worry about how to make ends meet."
item.content:encoded:
Both of Erin O’Dell’s parents are physical therapists, so physical therapy is in blood. When the time came for Erin to decide where to study to become a physical therapist for real, the UI Graduate Program in Physical Therapy and Rehabilitation Science’s reputation as the third-ranked program in the nation made the UI an easy choice.

Gifts from friends and alumni have helped Erin pay her way through school and created great opportunities for her in a first-rate learning environment—and when she’s providing compassionate, skilled care to her patients, those donors can all take pride in contributing to a healthier society.

item.title: Erin Kytola
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Financial help is such a great benefit. Without it, none of my experiences would have been possible."
item.content:encoded:
When Des Moines native Erin Kytola visited the University of Iowa campus during her junior year of high school, she fell in love with what she saw on campus. She also fell in love with Iowa’s opportunities.

“I wasn’t sure about what I wanted to do at that time,” Erin said. “And the UI offered the most majors and options for me to explore that.”

Erin—now a double major in journalism and ethics and public policy in the School of Journalism and Mass Communication in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, with a minor in business—credits the freedom she had to explore her interests for making confident academic choices. Those choices led to even more opportunities for Erin, including an internship with the Public Relations Student Society of America.

While such opportunities were a draw for Erin, so too was generous financial support. She received an Old Gold Scholarship, an award that played a role in her decision to attend the UI. She has continued to benefit from private support, receiving the Mark Westerbeck Memorial Scholarship—presented to her at the Fourth Estate Banquet, where she was able to meet her contributors and thank them in person.

“Financial help is such a great benefit,” said Erin. “Without it, none of my experiences would have been possible.”

And for Erin, the evidence of private support has gone well beyond scholarship awards. “We’re never at want for the technology we need, and it would be hard to get a job after graduation without that experience,” she said.

Her hope is that continued private support will provide future students with the opportunities she has enjoyed. She believes the impact of that support extends well beyond what happens on campus.

“The work done at Iowa’s journalism school affects the world,” she said.

item.title: Ellie Catton
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I couldn't have continued at Iowa without private support - and I can't imagine what my life would be like if I hadn't stayed and finished."
item.content:encoded:
If Ellie Catton’s life were a novel, its words would whisper of wind-swept glaciers in New Zealand and tree-lined boulevards in a small Midwestern city. Its characters would include a cast of talented and fiercely honest writers. And its denouement would happen through a last-minute change of heart—and the power of private support.

That support is what turned chance into good fortune for Ellie, after the New Zealand author came to the University of Iowa Writers’ Workshop—a unit of the UI College of Liberal Arts and Sciences—in 2008. The 25-year-old novelist, who recently made the short list of nominees for the prestigious Dylan Thomas Prize for her 2008 book, The Rehearsal, was in fine company in the program. Begun in 1936 as the nation’s first creative-writing degree program, the illustrious Iowa Writers’ Workshop is marking its 75th anniversary, with decades’ worth of famous and award-winning poets and authors among its graduates.

One of the first UI students to receive an M.A. degree in creative writing was poet Paul Engle, whose collection, Worn Earth, earned him the Yale Series of Younger Poets Prize. Engle assumed directorship of the Workshop in 1941 and held it for 25 years, during which the program became a literary powerhouse.

This reputation was what drew Ellie—who says she can’t recall a time in her life when she didn’t write—to Iowa. She arrived at the Workshop on a one-year exchange, after completing a master’s degree in creative writing at Victoria University of Wellington. When her Iowa tenure ended, the Workshop’s faculty asked the young novelist to stay on for another year. However, she declined—and was just 10 days away from flying home when she changed her mind.

“I confessed to a Workshop friend that I’d made a terrible mistake. He encouraged me to tell them I wanted to stay, but I thought it was hopeless,” Ellie says.

“When I called, they immediately found funding for me. I couldn’t have continued at Iowa without private support—and I can’t imagine what my life would be like if I hadn’t stayed and finished,” says the 2010 graduate, who received the Flannery O’ Connor Graduate Fellowship—created through a gift commitment from the Ralph Schultz Family Foundation of Waterloo, Iowa—and the Taylor-Chehak Prize, established by novelist Susan Taylor Chehak and her father, Robert Taylor.

“There is just something sacred about the Workshop,” says Ellie. “While you’re there, you’re saying what you honestly feel, but you’re also conscious of the fact that the author is listening. It’s an interesting psychological exercise.”

Ellie completed her first book on her family’s home computer at age nine and still indulges her childhood fascination with “sentences and syntax.” She currently is teaching at The University of Iowa while “pulling strange all-nighters” to finish her second novel—set in 1860s New Zealand—for Granta, a publisher in the United Kingdom.

Once it’s done, Ellie hopes to move to Canada to complete a Ph.D. degree in English literature and, perhaps, teach creative writing. No matter where she finds herself, she will carry with her all the words worth remembering from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop. And they will help create the next chapters of her life.

item.title: Elizabeth Schorsch
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I've actually been able to cut my expenses with each successive year. And that has allowed me to take advantage of all of the diverse opportunities here."
item.content:encoded:
Elizabeth Schorsch came to the University of Iowa expecting to follow one set path but found herself branching out in new directions once she was here.

“Originally, I came here for the creative-writing program,” said the Chicago native. “Once I was here for a bit, I realized that I no longer wanted to pursue creative writing academically, but I was glad that Iowa is a big school with strong liberal arts so that I could explore my other interest areas.”

Among those interests were history and education, and Elizabeth has done her share of exploration in each. She is now a double major in history and education policy in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, and she created her latter major herself, with help from the college’s Department of Interdepartmental Studies.

“This is a pretty unique program that allows driven students who are interested in pursuing a field of study or a career path that isn’t provided in the traditional departments or colleges to create their own majors,” Elizabeth said. “It’s really a wonderful process that forces you to figure out what it is you really want to pursue for your future.”

Elizabeth’s college exploration has taken her far beyond campus as well; she spent a month in western Ukraine teaching English for a university. On campus, she works as a writing and rhetoric tutor for her residence-hall tutoring program, and she has acted as a peer mentor for the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. In each of these roles, Elizabeth cites the help she is able to provide for others as motivation.

As the recipient of three scholarships—the UI National Scholars Award, the Old Gold Scholarship, and the Maxine J. Hibbs Scholarship—Elizabeth credits private support with transforming her UI experience.

“Because of that aid, I’ve actually been able to cut my expenses with each successive year. And that has allowed me to take advantage of all of the diverse opportunities here—and even do things like go to Ukraine to teach,” Elizabeth said.

Elizabeth believes the best way to thank contributors is to make the most of the experiences they facilitate with their gifts. And as to whether or not she intends to make gifts of her own down the road, she can answer in one word: “Definitely,” she said.

item.title: Denver Brown
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "The academic curriculum in the PA program at Iowa is supplemented by outside learning and service opportunities."
item.content:encoded:
Denver Brown became interested in biology while attending high school in Becker, Minnesota. After a mission trip to Gambia, West Africa, following graduation, he was inspired to apply that interest to the need for good health care as a physician assistant.

The University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine’s top-ranked Physician Assistant Program lured him to Iowa City after completing his undergraduate studies at Winona State University in Minnesota. The small class sizes at the UI, excellent instructors and proximity to UI Hospitals and Clinics—all things private support enables—make him proud of his choice.

Denver received the Montgomery Physician Assistant Scholarship his first year in the graduate program. “Giving to this program is a great investment,” Denver says. “Health care is a huge need both in the United States and around the world. Physician assistants play a vital role in satisfying that need.”

After completing his degree, Denver is considering going abroad to spread the knowledge and experience he gained at the UI globally. Wherever he ends up, he’ll have generous alumni and friends to thank for helping him launch the career of his dreams.

item.title: David Osedo
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Growing up in Kenya, I had no idea that I would one day be studying in the United States."
item.content:encoded:
“Growing up in Kenya, I had no idea that I would one day be studying in the United States, providing medical care for everyone from Iowa schoolchildren to elderly South Dakota farmers. I am grateful for the private support that has helped make this possible.”

As a nontraditional student, private support has been vitally important for David Osedo. It has allowed him to focus on his studies in the UI Physician Assistant Program—and to complete his clinical rotations—without having to worry about his family’s financial situation. During one of these clinical rotations in South Dakota, David saw, firsthand, how physician assistants in rural settings change peoples’ lives. And that’s exactly what he plans to do after graduation.

item.title: David Fulcher
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "For me it's been such a wonderful experience at Iowa, I’ve had such a great time, and it’s expanded my academic horizons."
item.content:encoded:
Involvement in a young investors club during high school sparked an immediate interest in business and finance for David Fulcher, and eventually led him to the University of Iowa Henry B. Tippie College of Business. “For me it’s been such a wonderful experience at Iowa, I’ve had such a great time, and it’s expanded my academic horizions,” says David.

The Finance and Spanish double major has taken full advantage of his college experience. He was president of the Financial Management Association, and is active in Delta Sigma Pi (a co-ed business fraternity), studied abroad in Costa Rica and was a recipient of Tippie’s “21 Under 21″ award, which goes to the college’s outstanding student leaders.

“I had the opportunity to meet Mr. Tippie and thank him for all of his support. It was such a gratifying experience,” David said, referring to the 1949 UI graduate who gave $30 million to support the UI’s business college that now bears his name. David was also selected as a scholar for the Hawkinson Institute of Business Finance, a donor-funded professional development program that currently boasts nearly 100 percent job placement for its graduates.

David is grateful for all of the opportunities he’s had at Iowa, and has this to say to his fellow students. “Mr. Tippie mentioned that his very first gift was five dollars,” says David. “Any amount helps!”

item.title: Daniela Moga
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Education is somebody's ride, and it's great if you can help them go somewhere."
item.content:encoded:
Daniela Moga has a straightforward philosophy about private support: “Education is somebody’s ride, and it’s great if you can help them go somewhere.”

And she would know. Hailing from Romania, her own ride was long, and was made possible by the financial support she received to attend the University of Iowa.

Daniela’s first exposure to the UI was on a visit as a Fogerty International Fellow. She knew about Iowa’s academic reputation, and she found something more on that visit.

“I fell in love with the place and the people,” she said.

Now in her final year as a Ph.D. student in the UI College of Public Health, Daniela was able to begin her journey through the UI by way of a pre-doctoral fellowship. She has since received an E. Peter Isaacson Scholarship, as well as various departmental awards from the College of Public Health. Daniela thanks contributors for allowing her to pursue her academic dreams, but she also expresses gratitude to the larger community for the personal support she’s found.

“The environment here allows me to be a good mom and a good student,” Daniela said.

Upon completing her studies in pharmecoepidemiology in May 2012, Daniela would like to continue working in a research capacity. She definitely plans to donate to the UI in the future: “I will do that. It allows people to pursue dreams, and it changes people’s lives.”

And as to what she would say to the contributors who helped pave her own road through the UI, Daniela has another simple message: “Thank you for changing my life.”

item.title: Daniel Pelzer
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I absolutely plan to give back when I'm able to do so. There are valuable programs here that need and deserve support."
item.content:encoded:
Daniel Pelzer’s first experiences with the University of Iowa happened years ago, amidst the towering exhibits inside the Museum of Natural History in Macbride Hall.

“I used to hang out in Macbride Hall as a kid while my mom shopped downtown,” Daniel said. “I’ve always felt a personal connection to the city.”

After completing undergraduate studies at the University of Northern Iowa, Daniel returned to Iowa City as a student in the University of Iowa Roy J. and Lucille A. Carver College of Medicine. He expects to graduate in May 2012 and plans to pursue a residency in pediatrics.

Growing up on a farm in Tipton, Iowa, Daniel may not have known he would one day be a doctor, but his childhood interests suggested such a path. He knew he wanted to explore something related to science as a career—and that he wanted to work with people. He sought a field that could marry those interests.

“Medicine is a blend of science and personal interaction,” said Daniel. “It’s a perfect way to interact with people and help improve their lives.”

While the personal connection Daniel forged during those childhood visits to campus played a role in his decision to choose the UI, so did the financial support he has received.

“I was looking at other schools out of state,” Daniel said. “I came here because of the great scholarships Iowa offered.” Daniel continues to see that support now. “The donors’ generosity doesn’t end with getting people in the door; they continue to support us throughout our education.”

As the recipient of multiple scholarships—including the Beisner Memorial Scholarship, the Iowa Medical Society Scholarship, and the Linder Family Scholarship—Daniel says meeting contributors at scholarship luncheons has been a personal highlight.

“Being able to put a face to a dollar amount is a great experience, for them and for me,” said Daniel. He plans to be a face of giving himself someday as well.

“I absolutely plan to give back when I’m able to do so. There are valuable programs here that need and deserve support, and so many ways my future money can benefit students.”

item.title: Danette Kapler
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Support from generous donors impacted my college career more than I could have ever imagined."
item.content:encoded:
When I first started as an editorial intern at The University of Iowa Foundation during the fall 2009 semester, I expected to learn more about writing, communications, and public relations in a higher-education setting. I gained a lot of experience in many different areas throughout the semester by writing stories, reading through various materials, and meeting with a variety of staff members about their careers. But I also learned something I did not expect—I learned about the impact that private support had on my college education and the vital role it will continue to play in the lives of University of Iowa students in the future.

As a journalism and mass communication major, I have been able to take advantage of the resources in the Philip D. Adler Journalism and Mass Communication Building. Built in 2005, the building received more than $6 million in private funding to make the construction possible. Prior to my internship, I did not pay attention to the names posted on the walls outside of classrooms and offices or the list of names on the large plaque near the entrance. Now I realize that those names represent individuals who care about the University, its students, and the journalism profession, and gave their hard-earned dollars to the building campaign to help ensure that journalism students’ education would be the best it could possibly be.

One of my favorite spots on the UI campus is the rotunda area in the Adler Journalism Building. It’s the perfect place for relaxing in between classes, studying, or catching up on the latest news on one of the television screens in the area. I know that without the support of generous donors, the rotunda where I spent hours of my college career would not exist. The building itself is not the only area where private support has had an impact. I have been able to utilize the technology and programs that are available in classrooms and resource centers. I have also had the opportunity to listen to many different guest speakers in a variety of different professions from all across the world who bring career advice and real-world perspectives to journalism classes.

After graduating from The University of Iowa in December 2009, I plan to move back to my hometown of Waterloo and one day pursue a career in higher education or government relations. My college experiences have played a big role in my career aspirations, and I know that without donor support, many of these experiences would not have been possible. During my first three years as a UI student, I never really thought about philanthropy. I assumed that tuition costs paid for all of my education. After interning with The University of Iowa Foundation, I realize that support from generous donors impacted my college career more than I could have ever imagined, and will continue to impact students in the future.

item.title: Danae Cole
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Thanks to contributors, I'll also be able to give back to others someday."
item.content:encoded:
The first day that Danae Cole walks into a patient’s room as a professional nurse—freshly graduated from The University of Iowa— she won’t be nervous.

The reason is simple: Contributors to the UI have helped the UI College of Nursing prepare Danae for her career in uniquely valuable ways.

For instance, Danae, a Des Moines native, has had extensive experience working in the college’s Nursing Clinical Education Center (NCEC). The college has used gift funds to establish and operate NCEC, a 20,000—square—foot center that includes an 11-room practice clinic where Danae has learned to administer sophisticated care in simulated exam rooms and other lifelike settings.

“Working in NCEC has given me extra confidence,” Danae says, expressing her thanks to contributors who have helped make the experience possible. “I’ve been able to practice assesment and treatment skills in a safe environment where I can make and fix mistakes, and learn from them.”

Danae has also recieved financial assistance from the college, thanks to private gifts, and she is grateful for the scholarship support that has allowed her to devote herself to learning her profession. For instance, the college worked with Danae to design and independent honors project presenting her discoveries from a private trip to the Demorcatic Republic of Congo, where she worked with malaria and HIV/AIDS patients and helped vaccinate children in a local clinic.

“Receiving scholarships has made it possible for me to concentrate on my studies and bring my personal experiences into my education, and opportunities like the NCEC have really helped me prepare for the real world of nursing,” Danae who plans a career in women’s health and working with underserved populations, says. “I’m pursuing all my goals at the UI. It’s been a great experience!”

item.title: Dan LeClere
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: “I can see myself giving back in different ways in the future because I know how much it helps out.”
item.content:encoded:
Growing up a wrestler in Coggon, Iowa, Dan LeClere always pictured himself wrestling for the Iowa Hawkeyes. He grew up attending Iowa wrestling meets with his dad and participated in the Hawkeye Kids Wrestling School, so he became familiar at an early age with the facilities and coaches at Iowa.

After winning four state titles for North-Linn High School, LeClere had a choice to make. He could not see himself wrestling for any other coaching staff besides Tom Brands’s. LeClere had been introduced to the coaches at a young age and grew up idolizing them. But Brands became the head coach at Virginia Tech after being an assistant coach with the Hawkeyes from 1993 until 2004. After years of dreaming of wearing Hawkeye black and gold, LeClere followed Brands to Virginia Tech.

Now, LeClere has the best of both worlds—the coach and the team he’d always wanted. In 2006 Brands took the head coaching job for the Hawkeyes, and LeClere was one of the student-athletes who followed him.

Transferring to Iowa resulted in a loss of one year of eligibility for LeClere, but he knows he would not be as successful as he is now had he not returned to his home state. LeClere received the Nile Kinnick Leadership Scholarship for his successes. “Earning a scholarship named for Nile Kinnick gives me a feeling of accomplishment,” he says. “It’s good to know all of my hard work is paying off.”

LeClere realizes the difficulty in balancing academics with athletics and says his scholarship has helped him with some of the burdens of college life. “When you stop and think about it, the support really means a lot,” he says. “I can see myself giving back in different ways in the future because I know how much it helps out.” A senior biology major and an academic all-Big Ten honoree, LeClere plans to pursue a career as a chiropractor once he graduates from the UI. But first, he is looking forward to his last Hawkeye wrestling season, and he thanks the fans for their endless support.

“Hawkeye fans are the greatest fans there are,” LeClere says. “We know our fans are always going to be behind us.”

item.title: Courtney Gent
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Scholarships make a tremendous impact on a student’s college education and experience."
item.content:encoded:
A job-shadowing experience in high school paved the way for Courtney Gent, who will graduate from the UI College of Pharmacy in May of 2012. “I really enjoyed my experience shadowing a hospital pharmacist, and I realized pharmacists are a very important element of patient care,” notes Courtney. Courtney completed three years of undergraduate studies at Iowa before being accepted into the College of Pharmacy. She’s glad to be at Iowa, and credits lab simulations and classroom experiences, along with job-shadowing opportunities, for giving her a solid academic foundation.

The Wellman, Iowa, native has been the recipient of several scholarships while enrolled at the UI, including a Pharmacy Tuition Scholarship, the Schlumberger Estate Scholarship, and the H. Curtis Snyder Scholarship.

“Scholarships make a tremendous impact on a student’s college education and experience,” says Courtney. They’ve allowed me to focus on academics, volunteer in the profession, and hold leadership roles in student organizations, without worrying as much about the cost of tuition.”

item.title: Christopher Blanco
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Going out, getting my degree, and representing the UI is the best thanks I can give."
item.content:encoded:
California native Christopher Blanco had three main priorities for selecting a law school: “I wanted good academics, resources to work with, and the opportunity to work for a football team,” said Christopher. He found all three-and more-at the University of Iowa.

Christopher is in his final year in the University of Iowa College of Law, and he also works as a football recruiting intern for the Hawkeyes. He came to the UI after completing undergraduate studies in sociology at Dartmouth College and has been seizing opportunity ever since.

Christopher is a member of the Latino/a American Law School Association and a co-founder of the Sports Law Society, and he worked with Professor Johnson in the College of Law to start a new course in sports law. After graduation in May 2012, he would like to carry what he’s learned at the UI in law and sports to the National Football League, hopefully working in player personnel.

Christopher counts private support among the reasons he’s had such valuable Iowa opportunities. He is the recipient of the Law Opportunity Fellowship and the Thurgood Marshall Legal Education Opportunity Program Fellowship, and he knows how he plans to show his gratitude for such support.

“Going out, getting my degree, and representing the UI is the best thanks I can give,” Christopher said. He also plans to return the favor someday.

“I’ve benefited a lot from the professors who have gone above and beyond for me. If my gift can help enable them to continue doing that, then it’s worth it.”

item.title: Chris Page
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I can't imagine what life would be like if I was in lots of debt. I feel very grateful that I have the support of so many generous donors."
item.content:encoded:
On the surface, it seems like Chris Page opted to stay close to home for college. The Iowa City native first started taking classes at The University of Iowa during his senior year of high school and chose to enroll for undergraduate studies after receiving a UI Presidential Scholarship. But while at Iowa, this political science and geography double major has taken three separate study-abroad trips to China and another to London. His time in China during the 2008 earthquake was especially life-changing, and led him to pick up the geography major–hoping to one day help solve international environmental problems.

Chris’s life on campus is equally exciting. He serves as finance chair for the UI Lecture Committee, and played a key role in partnering with the UI Office of Sustainability to bring environmentalist Bill McKibben to Iowa City. He’s also in the UI Honors Program, and was recently awarded a prestigious Truman Scholarship for graduate studies.

This ambitious student credits his full-tuition Presidential Scholarship for allowing him to have a well-rounded college experience, without worrying about debt.

“That support really made it for me,” Chris said. “I can’t imagine what life would be like if I was in lots of debt. I feel very grateful that I have the support of so many generous donors.”

Chris hopes to “pay it forward” after he graduates.

“People would be surprised at how even a small donation can make a difference in a student’s life,” Chris said, explaining why he hopes to support the UI in the future. “Now that I’ve had all of these amazing opportunities, I want to continue that giving.”

item.title: Catharyn Turner
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Your gift makes a strong statement about the importance of mentoring and empowering the next generation."
item.content:encoded:
Before coming to the UI Carver College of Medicine, Catharyn taught the seventh grade for 10 years in Maryland and Delaware. She instructed her students on more than English and Chemistry; she taught them about leading fulfilling lives and following their dreams.

They encouraged her to do the same—and now she is pursuing her own lifelong dream to become a pediatrician. As a UI-educated doctor, she looks forward to making an even bigger difference in kids’ lives—and gifts from friends and alumni help her reach that goal.

item.title: Cassie Gonzales
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "It's great that the college makes it so easy to explore different things while still focusing on my major."
item.content:encoded:
When Cassie Gonzales received the UI’s Opportunity at Iowa scholarship, given to students of minority heritage with high academic achievement, she jumped at the chance to come to the UI to study anthropology.

“I love to study people,” the Tucson, Arizona, native says.

To Cassie’s delight, she’s found that the interdisciplinary structure of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences is allowing her to study people in more ways than one.

In addition to the coursework for her anthropology major, Cassie is exploring other disciplines. She’s studying playwriting through the Department of Theatre Arts. She’s taking classes through the School of Journalism and Mass Communication. And with Cassie’s curious mind and the almost inexhaustible offerings of the college, only time will tell where her interests take her next.

A voracious reader and a talented artist—she teaches children’s art classes through the Tucson parks department during the summer—Cassie has found other projects of the college to her liking as well. She’s enjoyed the Iowa New Play Festival, for instance, and she attends readings made possible by the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and the Department of English.

“It’s been a fun experience,” Cassie says. “I’m looking forward to seeing where my education takes me. It’s great that the college makes it so easy to explore different things while still focusing on my major.”

Cassie is precisely the kind of bright, eager student who thrives in the wide-ranging creative and intellectual atmosphere of the college. And that comprehensive learning environment is made possible in large part by the thousands of contributors who give each year to the college or one or more of its departments.

People studying people, in many different ways: That’s what the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences is all about. And Cassie’s ready to dig in.

item.title: Brett Van Sloten
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "The scholarships at Iowa are so important, and the facilities are great. And because of donors, guys like me get a chance to play here."
item.content:encoded:
Emerging from the Kinnick Stadium tunnel and swarming the field with teammates in front of 70,000 Hawkeye faithful was something Brett Van Sloten knew he wanted to do in college. Now a junior, the Hawkeye offensive lineman is thankful to have the opportunity to do that, and more, at the University of Iowa.

“The coaches and players, the rich traditions, and the business school–my time at Iowa has been a great experience so far,” he says.

While football and the academic reputation of Iowa were draws for Brett, he also counts private support among the reasons he chose to don the black and gold.

“I was looking at other schools, but Iowa offered me a scholarship,” Brett says. And that made all the difference for him.

Brett has received support from the Al Grady Memorial Football Scholarship and the Arthur E. Stanley Football Scholarship Fund, and that support has given him what he calls “the opportunity of a lifetime” to play football at Iowa. But football is not all he has been thankful for in his time so far on campus.

The Decorah, Iowa, native and business management major has had rich experiences beyond the field of play as well. Throughout the summer of 2012, he took his business education beyond the classroom through an internship opportunity at the UI Foundation. Among the many benefits of the experience, his time at the foundation deepened his appreciation for the impact of private support on student-athletes.

“It takes a lot of support to run a successful football program,” he says. “The scholarships at Iowa are so important, and the facilities are great. And because of donors, guys like me get a chance to play here.”

item.title: Brett Greenwood
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: “We’re provided with everything we need to succeed as players and academically.”
item.content:encoded:
Iowa Hawkeye defensive back Brett Greenwood knows a thing or two about the value of athletic scholarships.

The starting free safety—named a 2010 preseason honorable mention All-American by NationalChamps.net—was a walk-on as a freshman at Iowa after his multi-position career at Pleasant Valley High School in Bettendorf, Iowa. He knows that every student-athlete with a scholarship had to work hard to receive the honor, but having to earn his as a walk-on made it all the sweeter.

“It felt great to get the recognition,” says Brett, who has received the Ben Trickey Memorial Scholarship, the Jack and Ailene Liechty Football Scholarship, and the Wallace Geiger Scholarship. “My hard work paid off.”

Brett, a marketing major, also worked as an intern for the Athletic Development Office at The University of Iowa Foundation during the summer of 2010. There he got to see firsthand the generosity and loyalty of many Hawkeye fans who step up to ensure that he and other UI student-athletes can earn a world-class education while wearing the black and gold.

“If not for them, we wouldn’t get our education and get to play for the Hawkeyes,” he says. “We’re provided with everything we need to succeed as players and academically.”

Brett, who for the fourth straight year was chosen in 2010 by his teammates to be a member of the Hawkeyes Leadership Group, knows he’ll always look back and remember all the ways Hawkeye fans support their team.

“When you come down that tunnel with the team and Kinnick Stadium opens up, there’s nothing like it,” he says. And he has a message for everyone who helps his teammates and him succeed: “Thank you for contributing throughout the year—and especially on football Saturdays.”

item.title: April Bachinski
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Thanks to generous alumni and friends, I can learn what I need to know to make a difference."
item.content:encoded:
“Thanks to generous alumni and friends, I can learn what I need to know to make a difference in my patients’ lives, day in and day out.”

During her very first clinical rotation, in the adult oncology unit, April Bachinski realized that she had embarked upon a truly rewarding journey by enrolling in the UI College of Nursing. What she learned during this first rotation was remarkable—and it was just one of many eye-opening experiences she’s had in the college’s Master of Science in Nursing: Clinical Nurse Leader program. April feels confident that these opportunities will help her fulfill her goal of working as a staff nurse at UI Hospitals and Clinics—and perhaps, one day, becoming a traveling nurse.

item.title: Andy Hunsberger
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I feel more well rounded, more cultured, and more confident as a result of the experience."
item.content:encoded:
Not many think of a performing arts center as having “alumni.” But for the UI graduates who serve as ushers, backstage hands, café workers, and box office cashiers, their time at Hancher Auditorium is a central—and often life-changing—part of their UI student experience.

Private support from contributors helps fund some Hancher student positions and create invaluable learning opportunities for UI students each year.

Andy Hunsberger, who worked at Hancher for nearly five years before graduating in December 2005, agrees that the experience has been invaluable.

“I’ve loved working at Hancher more than I can put into words,” says Andy. “I’ve gotten to see so many incredible performances, which have provided an amazing arts education.

“I’ve also built close relationships with other staff members—people with a broad range of backgrounds and interests that I probably wouldn’t have met otherwise. The experience has really enriched my UI education.“

Andy served as an usher for the first three years of his Hancher career and was promoted to house manager during the 2004-2005 season. In this role, he oversaw the student usher staff—helping with hiring, training, and supervising ushers, problem-solving during performances, and a variety of other high-responsibility tasks.

Andy, who plans to become a high school history teacher, is grateful to Hancher and its supporters for helping to make this learning opportunity possible.

“Working at Hancher really helped me mature and figure out my identity during my college years. I feel more well rounded, more cultured, and more confident as a result of the experience.”

item.title: Andrew Thomas
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Helping one student do his best work, by making unique opportunities available, raises the bar for all students."
item.content:encoded:
Andrew Thomas likes to think fast.

Whether it’s making cases as president of the UI Mock Trial Club or cracking jokes as a member of the improvisational comedy group Paperback Rhino, Andrew needs to be able to work with complex ideas and turn them around quickly and concisely.

He chose the right UI college.

“The most important part of what I’ve learned in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences is how to communicate well—writing, articulation, and persuasion skills,” Andrew says. “With those abilities, I feel like I’ll be able to go in any direction I choose.”

Andrew, a UI Presidential Scholar, has been setting the stage for those choices -– including attending Yale Law School –- by taking advantage of opportunities in the college to make the most of his UI experience. With support from the college’s Dewey Stuit Fund—designed to support students’ research—and other resources made possible by gifts large and small, Andrew has delved into his education and taken it beyond the classroom. For instance, he’s helped political science professor Brian Lai compile a searchable database of global terrorist incidents and research the role of the U.S. in halting international money laundering.

Andrew served as president of the college’s Dean’s Student Advisory Council—working with the dean’s office on issues of importance to students—and and as the chief of staff and public relations executive for UI Student Government. An active member of the Honors Program, he was awarded the Collegiate Scholar Award, and was selected to speak at the CLAS commencement ceremony in 2006, at which he graduated with highest distinction and honors. Andrew was also awarded a Hancher-Finkbine Medallion by the UI, as recognition of his outstanding academic success and service to the University.

He’s thankful for the ways that private support has helped him excel in his studies—and mindful of the effects of private gifts on the college as a whole.

“My Presidential Scholarship has helped me focus on what I’m most interested in,” Andrew says. “And helping one student do his best work, by making unique opportunities available, raises the bar for all students.”

item.title: Ali Keenan
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "Each award makes me think more grandly about the world—and makes me feel more empowered to change it for the better."
item.content:encoded:
As a nine-year-old in Urbandale, Iowa, Ali Keenan accompanied her dad, a firefighter, to a free flu-shot clinic that he had organized at the fire station for low-income members of the community. It was the first time Ali realized that not everybody had access to medical care.

“I didn’t understand,” said Ali, a Presidential Scholar who will graduate from the UI next May with degrees in engineering, biochemistry, and international studies. “And I didn’t think it was fair. The sense of injustice drove me crazy.”

Ali’s passion for fairness continues to motivate her, while her clear-eyed vision for the future and knack for problem-solving have already helped her find ways to start correcting health-care injustices, all over the world.

Last year, working with College of Engineering professor Craig Just (also the coordinator of sustainability programs for the college), Ali and a team of 14 of her classmates from the college’s chapter of Engineers for a Sustainable World created a handheld, hand-cranked device that turns salt water into chlorine bleach. The device can be assembled almost anywhere, using about five dollars’ worth of readily available materials—a recycled plastic soda bottle, for instance—and generates enough bleach with each use to kill the disease-causing microorganisms in about five gallons of water. That could mean the difference between life and death for millions; by some estimates, 5,000 children worldwide die each day from diarrhea-related diseases, most of which are attributable to unsafe water supply.

Discover magazine selected the device as one of its “10 Everyday Technologies that Can Change the World,” saying that, “For the roughly 1.2 billion people lacking clean water, a bit of chlorine could go a long way toward providing it.” The invention also won first place in the Environmental Protection Agency’s fourth annual People, Prosperity, and the Planet (P3 Awards) competition—an honor that awarded the team $75,000 to further develop the project.

Those accolades alone would be enough to warrant attention—and admiration—for Ali Keenan. But at age 23, with support from contributors to the University through the UI Foundation, Ali has already amassed an impressive résumé of experiences that merge her skills of invention with her genuine concern for the needs of people in the developing world. She has cared for HIV-positive orphans in Mexico and provided cervical-cancer screenings and entrepreneurship assistance to impoverished women in India. She works with the UI Mobile Clinic to provide free cholesterol and diabetes screenings for underserved patients in the Iowa City area. For her senior design project, she is developing a cheap and portable optical test to detect malaria in the field—and she just spent the summer in India, teaching clinicians techniques for diagnosing leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease that she has been researching in a UI lab for two years through the Iowa Center for Research by Undergraduates.

You won’t catch Ali gloating about her considerable accomplishments, though—in fact, she seems a little embarrassed by the attention of being the “it” girl on campus these days.

“I’m just learning as much as I can, and trying to do some good along the way,” she said. “I’ve been very lucky to find great mentors and financial support, both of which have been 100 percent necessary in helping me achieve my goals.”

Thankfully for all of us, the UI and its contributors have been here to help Ali channel her passions into practical solutions to some of the world’s most intractable problems. The significant support she’s received to pay for her education and to fund her trips and research, through numerous scholarships and through funds supported by contributors to her academic programs, has empowered Ali to reach for goals that few can imagine.

“From the time I got my first scholarship, every ounce of support has opened new doors of opportunity. Each award makes me think more grandly about the world—and makes me feel more empowered to change it for the better.”

That’s the power of investing in especially promising University of Iowa students. In Ali’s case, the multiplying effect of student support has already saved lives in far-flung places. There’s no telling how many lives she will save or improve as she makes her way in the world. She wants to continue working to put existing medical technologies into the hands of people who need them by making them simpler and more affordable, and by engineering social programs to deliver the tools to wherever they are most needed.

Charitable giving will probably help sustain Ali’s career for years to come, considering that delivering diagnostic tools and medicines to the developing world is not exactly a high-profit pursuit.

“I feel good about reaching out to the world on behalf of the generous people who have supported my education,” Ali said. “And I have faith that I’ll be able to count on that generosity as long as I want to continue this kind of work.”

item.title: Alex Ingham
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I was impressed with the academic standards here, and getting a Presidential Scholarship helped finalize my decision."
item.content:encoded:
Alex Ingham is going to make the world a better place.

No matter what career he chooses—perhaps as an international diplomat, a Peace Corps employee, or an English teacher in a foreign country—Alex knows that an outstanding education from the UI College of Liberal Arts and Sciences (CLAS) will equip him to make a positive impact in the world.

In addition to his major coursework in political science and international studies, Alex is exploring other disciplines. Studying a wide range of topics from history to film theory, and from Chinese to design for the developing world, Alex is getting a remarkably broad education—and making important connections in the process.

Alex is learning comprehensive communication and critical-thinking skills that will prepare him to be a knowledgeable citizen of the 21st century and empower him to meet the challenges of a rapidly changing world.

“I chose the UI because I want to learn as much as possible, without limitations,” Alex says. “My interests are diverse, and the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences is the perfect place to explore them.

“I was impressed with the academic standards here, and getting a Presidential Scholarship helped finalize my decision. It validated my past work, and made me want to continue to excel.”

Private support helps provide the resources for Alex—and other high-caliber UI students—to do just that.

Gifts to CLAS—or any of its more than 40 departments, schools, and programs—help provide support for great professors, access to up-to-the-minute technology, and an ever-changing slate of public lectures, performances, and exhibitions that make the UI campus an exciting place to learn.

“I’m never bored here, and the learning never stops,” Alex says.

Thanks in large part to thoughtful and loyal contributors to the UI College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, it never will.

item.title: Adam Haluska
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "I'm amazed at how many people I meet who just want to make sure that my teammates and I have the best experience and the best education possible."
item.content:encoded:
When Adam Haluska was growing up in Carroll, Iowa, he idolized former Hawkeye men’s basketball greats Chris Street and Jess Settles, and fantasized about wearing the black and gold himself one day.

Now—after a brief detour at Iowa State—he’s realized his dream.

“To be in that Iowa locker room is an overwhelming feeling,” says Adam, a starting guard. “I’m thankful to be able to step on the court for every practice or game.”

Hawkeye fans are thankful that Adam’s there, too:

  • He’s an ironman—as of the end of the 2005-2006 season, he’d started all 98 games in his career, the 10th-longest streak in the nation heading into the 2006-07 season.
  • He was the 2006 winner of the Chris Street Award, named in honor of Adam’s Hawkeye hero and presented annually to an Iowa player who best exemplifies the spirit, enthusiasm, and intensity of Chris Street (Street died in an auto accident January 19, 1993, midway through his junior year).
  • He’s been named all-Big Ten, academic all-Big Ten, and academic all-American.

In other words, Adam gives everything he’s got to his University.

And he’s inspired to do so in part by all those who give so much to support him and his fellow Hawkeye student-athletes—from the cheering fans to the contributors who endow scholarships through the Hawkeye Visions initiative to the thousands of I-Club members who help the UI cover the day-to-day costs of Hawkeye athletics.

“People take for granted what it takes to have an athletics program,” Adam says. “Every time I go to an I-Club event, I’m amazed at how many people I meet who just want to make sure that my teammates and I have the best experience and the best education possible. It’s what makes Iowa a great University.”

item.title: Abdul Hodge & Chad Greenway
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "From scholarships to Kinnick Stadium to things like the Gerdin Athletic Learning Center, we all really appreciate their support."
item.content:encoded:
Iowa football players Chad Greenway and Abdul Hodge come from vastly different backgrounds, one rural and the other urban. But they have an unbreakable bond that’s stronger than any differences: Iowa Hawkeye pride.

Chad and Abdul are two of the premier linebackers in the nation. Iowa’s Big Ten and national rivals would love to have these pre-season All-Americans—both are on the watch lists for the Chuck Bednarik Award, the Lott Trophy, and the Lombardi Award—but these dedicated Hawkeyes wouldn’t trade the experience of playing for Head Coach Kirk Ferentz in Kinnick Stadium for anything.

“Kinnick Stadium is one of the greatest places I’ve ever played,” says Chad. “No matter the weather, the fans are always there, showing how much they love the Hawkeyes. It’s a unique environment.”

Chad and Abdul say Iowa fans’ financial support is another message they and their fellow student-athletes hear loud and clear.

“I enjoy talking with I-Club groups and thanking them for all they do for us,” says Abdul. “From scholarships to the Kinnick Stadium renovation to things like the Gerdin Athletic Learning Center, we all really appreciate their support.”

Thanks to I-Club members and other contributors, the future is bright for well-educated, talented UI student-athletes like Chad and Abdul. And no matter where these two go after graduating, they will always share a common heritage, forged on the football field in Hawkeye black and gold.

item.title: Aaron Porter
item.dc:creator: givetoiowa
item.description: "The rate of progress in the College of Public health is phenomenal.”
item.content:encoded:
As a Ph.D. student at the University of Iowa College of Public Health, Aaron Porter is no stranger to the university classroom experience. Before coming to the UI, he attended two other schools to earn bachelor’s and master’s degrees, and the caliber of teaching and collaboration at Iowa stands out.

“Every day I walk through the doors of the College of Public Health, I’m happier and happier I chose to come here,” says Aaron, who is from a northern Chicago suburb. “I knew within 24 hours of visiting that this was the school I would attend—I could feel the camaraderie between faculty and students within the department.”

This camaraderie is important to Aaron, because he believes a significant part of the learning experience comes from conversations with faculty and other students outside of the classroom. The UI is ideal, he says, for this kind of interaction. “Within the first three weeks of my courses here, I could feel the difference,” Aaron says. The strength of the relationship between faculty, students, and education will only increase when the new academic building for the college is completed, something Aaron is eagerly anticipating.

Aaron, who was drawn to biostatistics because of the immediate, tangible impact the work can have on the world, will benefit from private gifts not only through his use of the new facility, but also as both a teaching and research assistant.

These and other contributions to the department are being used effectively, which Aaron says is evident in the solid program and reputation the college has built in its 10-year history, and are helping it continue to grow and improve. If his plans to teach at an institution that combines teaching and research lead him back to Iowa City one day, Aaron would be happy to consider the opportunity.
